          <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor even depth-2"> <a name="comment-313087"></a> 
           <div id="li-comment-313087" class="comment-container"> 
            <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
             <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-313087"> 
             <div class="avatar">
              <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">September 5, 2016 at 2:17 PM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-313087" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-313087"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hi Doreen,</p> 
               <p>Thanks for your comment and for visiting our website!</p> 
               <p>For Wix, if you want to connect your own domain name to your website, you’ll have to upgrade to at least their Connect Domain plan. </p> 
               <p>If you don’t mind using the Wix subdomain at the moment, then you don’t need to upgrade. You can keep using Wix’s free plan for an unlimited time until you are ready to upgrade later (or not).</p> 
               <p>There are certainly some advantages to upgrading. For instance, you’ll get better branding through your own custom domain name. This is important as you start to brand your business (or whatever your website is built for). So having a brand or a name to your website is definitely something you should consider, at least after you gain some traction and visitors to your website. </p> 
               <p>Further, if you upgrade to their Combo plan (or higher), you can remove the Wix advertisement from your website. This too, is something you can consider down the road if you want to focus on branding your website. </p> 
               <p>Hope this points you in the right direction!</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div> 
              <div class="reply"> 
               <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-313087" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-313087&quot;, &quot;313087&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
              </div> 
             </div> 
            </article> 
           </div> </li> 
         </ul> </li>

          <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor even depth-2"> <a name="comment-312993"></a> 
           <div id="li-comment-312993" class="comment-container"> 
            <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
             <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-312993"> 
             <div class="avatar">

             </div> 
             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">August 26, 2016 at 9:51 PM</span>

              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-312993"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hi Mike,</p> 
               <p>I don’t think Wix can provide the features you’re looking for. Sounds to me that you’re looking to build a marketplace (like eBay or Amazon), which is a specialized type of website. If you search for “marketplace website builders”, you’ll find a few options.</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p>

        <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1"> <a name="comment-311067"></a> 
         <div id="li-comment-311067" class="comment-container"> 
          <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
           <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-311067"> 
           <div class="avatar">
            <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/Logo-Avatar.png" width="40" height="40" alt="" class="avatar avatar-40wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo avatar-default">
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-head"> 
            <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Cathy</span> </span> 
            <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">August 1, 2016 at 9:36 AM</span> 
            <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-311067" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
            <span class="edit"></span> 
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-311067"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>I’d appreciate your insight about the issue of “owning” versus “renting” your site.<br> I’ve read some articles that mention that when you rent ultimately, you may not have full control over your site, nor have the ability to use elements for other social media or other platforms.<br> Although you mention WP as less user friendly then some of the others what are the options for ownership?</p> 
            </div> 
            <div class="reply"> 
             <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-311067" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-311067&quot;, &quot;311067&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Cathy">Reply</a> 
            </div> 
           </div> 
          </article> 
         </div> 
         <ul class="children"> 
          <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor even depth-2"> <a name="comment-311074"></a> 
           <div id="li-comment-311074" class="comment-container"> 
            <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
             <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-311074"> 
             <div class="avatar">
              <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">August 1, 2016 at 1:05 PM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-311074" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-311074"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hello Cathy,</p> 
               <p>That’s an interesting way of putting it. “Renting” being using a drag &amp; drop website builder where they provide you with all the technology and support you need to power your website, versus “Owning” meaning you have to build your site from scratch (almost), manage your own technology and basically play the role of an IT manager, at times (or hiring someone).</p> 
               <p>To take that idea further, it’s like building your own house versus renting a place where it’s move-in-ready. Building a house is not rocket science by any means, but it does take a lot more time, education, effort, energy, and a lot more financial capital. But at the end of the day, you can customize it. </p> 
               <p>With drag &amp; drop website builders, they’re “move-in-ready” so you can get a website up and running very quickly, but with some limitations as they lack the flexibility of having a custom built website.</p> 
               <p>If you want to control your website with a lot of flexibility, I’d definitely suggest WordPress. Other solutions can be a lot costlier and more challenging to manage (such as Joomla or Drupal). WordPress is probably the best “bang for your buck” when it comes to the amount of effort it takes to learn (or pay to have things configured / set up for you), versus the flexibility it offers you.</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div> 
              <div class="reply"> 
               <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-311074" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-311074&quot;, &quot;311074&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
              </div> 
             </div> 
            </article> 
           </div> </li> 
         </ul> </li>

             <p>Hello Mary,</p> 
             <p>Wow, 3 hours? Thanks so much for reading our discussions! Very flattering indeed.</p> 
             <p>It sounds to me that you need some sort of “social community website creator”. Search for that phrase in Google and you’ll find a few more suitable for your needs. </p> 
             <p>Website creators like Wix or Squarespace don’t have ability to help you create a community / social network.</p> 
             <p>Hope this points you in the right direction!</p>

            <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor odd alt depth-3"> <a name="comment-310920"></a> 
             <div id="li-comment-310920" class="comment-container"> 
              <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
               <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-310920"> 
               <div class="avatar">
                <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
               </div> 
               <div class="comment-head"> 
                <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
                <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">July 20, 2016 at 5:57 PM</span> 
                <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-310920" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
                <span class="edit"></span> 
               </div> 
               <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-310920"> 
                <div itemprop="text">
                 <p>Hey Martyn,</p> 
                 <p>I’m not sure if I fully understand the process. So do you mean the ability for your customer to email you their artwork, then you add the artwork on the product which you source from your supplier, then you send your customer the final product?</p> 
                 <p>If so, what you will probably need to do is email your customer each time you make a sale to ask them for the artwork. The actual sale between your customer and your store is fairly straight forward. They just visit your online store and purchase the product from you. Just list out on your product page that you will email them for the required information to be added on to the product, before shipping the final product to them.</p> 
                 <p>At least that is what I’d do. It’s sort of piecing together the process, as I haven’t seen an ecommerce creator that can integrate all these together.</p> 
                 <p>Jeremy</p> 
                </div> 
                <div class="reply"> 
                 <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-310920" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-310920&quot;, &quot;310920&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
                </div> 
               </div> 
              </article> 
             </div> </li>

         <div id="li-comment-310896" class="comment-container"> 
          <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
           <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-310896"> 
           <div class="avatar">
            <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/Logo-Avatar.png" width="40" height="40" alt="" class="avatar avatar-40wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo avatar-default">
           </div>

              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-310893" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-310893"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hi Don,</p> 
               <p>Any one of the website builders above will allow you to upload audio files so your web visitors can download them. You can also create a simple biography or “about me” page with any one of them.</p> 
               <p>If you really don’t know which website builder to experiment with, I’d suggest starting from the left side of our table above (i.e. Wix, Squarespace, Weebly). Wix is the best “All Around” website builder, at this point.</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div>

             <p>I am a newbie to website building, and I am completely overwhelmed. My site is powered by Powweb.<br> I struggled with them for years. In recent years they have improved their customer service to where I can finally get human help. I have my site up and running now but I don’t believe it is verified by Google yet. I will have to find help at Powweb to do that. My site was built using Weebly – the older version, I think. </p> 
             <p>But to get to my point, I am so glad to find your site. I wish I had found it before I even started my site. To someone who is a non-tekkie” type person, just learning what all the technical abbreviations meant was a problem. Thank you so much for this information.</p>

          <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor even depth-2"> <a name="comment-310889"></a> 
           <div id="li-comment-310889" class="comment-container"> 
            <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
             <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-310889"> 
             <div class="avatar">
              <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">July 18, 2016 at 10:46 AM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-310889" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-310889"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hello Patricia,</p> 
               <p>Thanks so much for sharing your comment with us. </p> 
               <p>To help your website become recognized by Google, try setting up <a href="https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/1142414?hl=en" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Google Search Console</a> where you can verify that you own the website. The help articles from Weebly / Powweb should be able to walk you through that. It does take some time for Google to process your site, so just be patient.</p> 
               <p>One thing to consider is to use Weebly.com directly. As you mentioned, the version of Weebly that Powweb offers is outdated. If you used Weebly.com directly, you’d receive assistance from their own support team, directly.</p> 
               <p>We have a <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/weebly-vs-weebly-with-bluehost/" target="_blank">discussion about that here</a>. The article talks about using Weebly directly, versus the version that Bluehost offers. Even though it is targeted at Bluehost, the idea is the same as if it was targeted at Powweb.</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div> 
              <div class="reply"> 
               <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-310889" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-310889&quot;, &quot;310889&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
              </div> 
             </div> 
            </article> 
           </div> </li>

              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-310818" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-310818"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hello Sheri,</p> 
               <p>I’d suggest you take a look at Wix and Weebly to start. Both of these website builders offer you newsletter capability (Wix Shoutout and Weebly Promote). See our Footnote 16 above for more discussions about them.</p> 
               <p>These newsletter tools are fully integrated with the website builders already, so they’re easy to set up and manage. WordPress is a really good and flexible platform, but it’s much more advanced and has a much steeper learning curve.</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div> 
              <div class="reply"> 
               <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-310818" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-310818&quot;, &quot;310818&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a>

        <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1"> <a name="comment-310785"></a> 
         <div id="li-comment-310785" class="comment-container"> 
          <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
           <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-310785"> 
           <div class="avatar">
            <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-head"> 
            <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
            <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">July 11, 2016 at 11:33 AM</span> 
            <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-310785" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
            <span class="edit"></span> 
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-310785"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Hey Jeff,</p> 
             <p>I’d suggest you check out Squarespace or Weebly. Both offer you responsive designs so websites built with these platforms are automatically mobile friendly. Wix is also mobile friendly, but they’re not responsive as you get a separate, dedicated mobile editor for Wix websites. So I think you might want to check them out as well.</p> 
             <p>You can definitely insert slideshows, setup dedicated areas / pages for your books, link out to the several places that you mentioned and create blog posts. Those are fairly basic functions that the website creators all have. </p> 
             <p>As for the ability to capture emails, Wix and Weebly have built in newsletter services (see footnote 16 above). So your visitors can subscribe to your newsletter series. </p> 
             <p>When it comes to “pizazz”, I’d suggest you take a look at Wix and Squarespace’s design templates. Both of these website creators probably offer you the most professional looking designs. </p> 
             <p>A prudent thing to do is sign up for to their free / trial accounts and invest some time into testing them out. That’s one of the best ways to help you make a more informed decision as to which website creator works best for your needs.</p> 
             <p>Jeremy</p> 
            </div> 
            <div class="reply"> 
             <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-310785" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-310785&quot;, &quot;310785&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
            </div> 
           </div> 
          </article> 
         </div>

        <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1"> <a name="comment-310768"></a> 
         <div id="li-comment-310768" class="comment-container"> 
          <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
           <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-310768"> 
           <div class="avatar">
            <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/Logo-Avatar.png" width="40" height="40" alt="" class="avatar avatar-40wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo avatar-default">
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-head"> 
            <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeff</span> </span> 
            <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">July 10, 2016 at 6:04 AM</span> 
            <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-310768" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
            <span class="edit"></span> 
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-310768"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Hi Jeremy,<br> I write for a living, and having swapped over to a new agent, she is quite strongly advising me to set up author websites for my two author names. I used to be happy with WPress four or five years ago, but I don’t need all the endless tweaking and SEO’ing that goes with WP, I need to be able to come up most days, post a few thoughts as easily as possible, and then concentrate on my work.</p> 
             <p>My needs are simple really – possibly a slide show of my books, an area for each book, a shopping area to buy each book, a link to the Amazon, Kobo and Apple bookshops where readers can buy also, an ability to allow free downloads of chapters/books, a blogging area that keeps readers updated with what I’m doing and where I am, and last but not least an email capture device.<br> Oops, forgot to list that I would like the facility to add photo’s to each blog post if needed and it needs to be responsive (as I know Gurgle’s algorithm penalises slow loading/non responsive sites).<br> And it has to have Pizazz, Real Pizazz.<br> Jeremy I’d appreciate your advice on the best platform, and buy via your link. BTW there are a lot of writers out there in the same boat, judging from the forums – I’m surprised that the big hitters haven’t cottoned on to the need (I’ve just had a quick look a Ukit and they have a template for a tattoo artist but not for a writer/author – bizarre).<br> Hope you can help!<br> Jeff</p> 
            </div> 
            <div class="reply"> 
             <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-310768" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-310768&quot;, &quot;310768&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeff">Reply</a> 
            </div> 
           </div> 
          </article> 
         </div> </li>

           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-310505"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Hello Jeremy, I’m old school .. have my websites on Frontpage and they bring me a lot of business.<br> I want to keep the look of what I have basically but have a modern engine under the hood of my old pickup (look) if you get my drift.</p> 
             <p>I keep looking at all the new websites, themes, etc. and I do not understand the concept of ‘theme’s” exactly.<br> My assumption is that a ‘theme’ is the composite of photos shown?<br> Or is a theme the structural design? What I mean is, if I find a website that I like the structure of pages and menus, can I get rid of the canned pictures and add my own in their place?</p> 
             <p>Thank you.</p> 
            </div> 
            <div class="reply"> 
             <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-310505" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-310505&quot;, &quot;310505&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Diana">Reply</a>

         <ul class="children"> 
          <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor even depth-2"> <a name="comment-310536"></a> 
           <div id="li-comment-310536" class="comment-container"> 
            <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
             <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-310536"> 
             <div class="avatar">
              <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">June 26, 2016 at 8:10 PM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-310536" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-310536"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hi Diana,</p> 
               <p>Yes you can. So if you like the theme (the structural design), you can remove the default images and text, as those are just there as placeholders to help illustrate what a website could potentially look like. </p> 
               <p>For instance, if you sign up to a trial account with Wix, and pick one of the themes / templates, you’ll very quickly see that you can move the pre-populated content around the site by just dragging and dropping them, and you can also delete these content or replace them with your own.</p> 
               <p>Hope this helps!</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div> 
              <div class="reply"> 
               <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-310536" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-310536&quot;, &quot;310536&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
              </div>

            </article> 
           </div> </li>

          <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor even depth-2"> <a name="comment-310495"></a> 
           <div id="li-comment-310495" class="comment-container"> 
            <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
             <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-310495"> 
             <div class="avatar">
              <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">June 23, 2016 at 8:01 PM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-310495" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-310495"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hello Michelle,</p> 
               <p>Yes – you can just connect your domain name from where it is held / registered, to your Squarespace website. To display your custom domain name on your Squarespace website, you’ll need to upgrade to at least one of its premium plans.</p> 
               <p>Squarespace has tutorials on how to connect your domain name in their support portal.</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div> 
              <div class="reply"> 
               <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-310495" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-310495&quot;, &quot;310495&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a>

        <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1"> <a name="comment-310470"></a> 
         <div id="li-comment-310470" class="comment-container"> 
          <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
           <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-310470"> 
           <div class="avatar">
            <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/Logo-Avatar.png" width="40" height="40" alt="" class="avatar avatar-40wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo avatar-default">
           </div>

           <div id="li-comment-310477" class="comment-container">

             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">June 22, 2016 at 1:30 AM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-310477" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-310477"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hello Brian,</p> 
               <p>For all of the website builders above, each individual website is upgraded on a standalone basis. So if you have 5 separate websites within your account, and you want to upgrade 3 of them to access more advanced tools / features, then you have to upgrade each of the 3.</p> 
               <p>Hope this clarifies things!</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div>

            <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

             <div class="avatar">

             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">June 12, 2016 at 10:56 PM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-310376" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-310376"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hi Cynthia,</p> 
               <p>Thanks for your comment! </p> 
               <p>If I’m understanding your question properly, I think that with Wix, you’ll have to update your listings the same way as Squarespace. I’m not aware of a way to import blocks of information. I think you’ll have to copy and paste data from your Word or Excel file into a Wix element (such as text).</p> 
               <p>As for site search function, Wix doesn’t have a “native” search function built in. However, you can bolt on 3rd party search apps directly into your Wix site. The benefit of using these apps is that they are configured to work properly with Wix websites. Visit their <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/go/wixapphome" target="_blank">App Market</a> and type in “search” to look for these apps.</p> 
               <p>Good luck!</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div>

              </div>

             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-310370"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hello Jerry,</p> 
               <p>Some website builders (for example, Wix and Weebly) do have third party forum apps that you can bolt on to your website. However, I’m not entirely sure how good they are as I’ve never built a forum with good amount of interactions before.</p> 
               <p>There is a community builder called Ning that you might want to check out. I’ve never used them before in my previous projects, so can’t assess them objectively. But check them out!</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p>

            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Hi Jeremy,</p> 
             <p>Thanks for all your wonderful information it is so helpful. I have two questions regarding Wix – after your feedback I have chosen to go with them for now.          <ul class="children"> 
          <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor even depth-2"> <a name="comment-310334"></a> 
           <div id="li-comment-310334" class="comment-container"> 
            <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
             <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-310334"> 
             <div class="avatar">
              <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">June 9, 2016 at 9:18 PM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-310334" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-310334"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hey Vanessa,</p> 
               <p>You can create as many websites as you want under one single Wix account. However, each website can only use one template, and each website can only have one domain name.</p> 
               <p>However, what you can try to do is create a sub-domain name. So for instance, for your main site you can use your normal domain name (such as example.com). For your blog (2nd website), you can use a sub-domain name, such as blog.example.com.</p> 
               <p>You should be able to do that through your domain name registrar (consult their support team on how to do that). </p> 
               <p>So you are “branding” both your websites using the same domain name. One is the main domain name, and the other is a sub-domain.</p> 
               <p>In terms of migrating to Shopify (one of the best ecommerce builders <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/shopify-reviews/" target="_blank">in our view</a>), it’s definitely possible. You can just disconnect your domain names that are pointed to your Wix websites, and reconnect them to your new Shopify sites. Shopify’s <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/go/shopifysupport" target="_blank">support portal</a> will show you how to connect domain names to online stores built by their platform.</p> 
               <p>Hope this helps!</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div> 
              <div class="reply"> 
               <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-310334" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-310334&quot;, &quot;310334&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
              </div> 
             </div> 
            </article> 
           </div> </li> 
         </ul> </li>

            <div class="reply"> 
             <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-310297" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-310297&quot;, &quot;310297&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Laura">Reply</a>

         <ul class="children"> 
          <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor even depth-2"> <a name="comment-310312"></a> 
           <div id="li-comment-310312" class="comment-container"> 
            <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
             <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-310312"> 
             <div class="avatar">
              <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">June 8, 2016 at 2:05 AM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-310312" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-310312"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hello Laura,</p> 
               <p>It really depends. Generally speaking, Shopify is the best platform for building ecommerce websites (if you haven’t seen our discussion about Shopify, <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/shopify-reviews/" target="_blank">you can see it here</a>). </p> 
               <p>Even though Wix is easier to use, Shopify offers more tools, support and general ecommerce ecosystem for online stores. </p> 
               <p>Once you get going and if your business start to grow larger, Shopify offers you much more advanced options, as well as the options of hiring specialists (design or developers) to help you customize your store. </p> 
               <p>The immediate drawback is that Shopify is a bit pricier. But they offer much broader options for you down the road.</p> 
               <p>Having said that, if you just want simpler tools, and an easier user interface where you can drag and drop content anywhere you want, then Wix is a good choice.</p> 
               <p>I’d go with either Shopify or Wix, before GoDaddy.</p> 
               <p>Hope this helps!</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div> 
              <div class="reply"> 
               <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-310312" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-310312&quot;, &quot;310312&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a>

        <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1"> <a name="comment-310293"></a> 
         <div id="li-comment-310293" class="comment-container">

           <div class="comment-head"> 
            <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jill</span> </span>

           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-310293"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Hello Jeremy!</p> 
             <p>Thank you for all your great information. I’m in a bit of a conundrum. </p> 
             <p>I am an online teacher and have taken some time to figure out the components I want to have in my website. And, I love (and am possibly semi-obsessed with) the designs on SquareSpace, so much so that I want to build my website on SquareSpace. </p> 
             <p>The tricky part is that I found a software I like that has the exact online classroom components that I need, but whose plug-in is not compatible with SquareSpace. This same software is compatible with WordPress. </p> 
             <p>Could you please offer me some advice as to what to do? Could I build my website on SquareSpace and then export it to WordPress, and add the plug-in there? And what exactly does it mean to export a website to WordPress? Or could I build my website on SquareSpace and then add a link for my online-classroom? </p> 
             <p>Thank you in advance for any input you can offer. </p> 
             <p>Kindest regards,<br> Jill</p>

         <ul class="children"> 
          <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor even depth-2"> <a name="comment-310311"></a> 
           <div id="li-comment-310311" class="comment-container"> 
            <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
             <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-310311"> 
             <div class="avatar">
              <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">June 8, 2016 at 1:59 AM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-310311" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-310311"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hi Jill,</p> 
               <p>The export function for Squarespace only exports your content. So when it comes to design, you’ll have to configure that in your WordPress account. Generally speaking, if you want to make edits to your WordPress website design, you’ll have to tweak the codes to do so (you can see our discussion about <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/squarespace-vs-wordpress/" target="_blank">Squarespace vs WordPress here</a>).</p> 
               <p>So the export approach might not work well for what you want. Functionally it might work, but design wise might not be what you’re looking for.</p> 
               <p>The option of building your main website on Squarespace, then building your online classroom separately, then linking up both sites – it just might work. Some people prefer not to do that as they want to control everything under one roof. Another thing is that the design of your website and the online classroom may not match. They’re not big deals for some people, but obviously those are personal choices. </p> 
               <p>If you don’t mind managing both platforms, the option you suggested will work.</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div> 
              <div class="reply"> 
               <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-310311" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-310311&quot;, &quot;310311&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
              </div> 
             </div> 
            </article> 
           </div> </li> 
         </ul> </li> 
        <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor odd alt thread-even depth-1"> <a name="comment-310167"></a> 
         <div id="li-comment-310167" class="comment-container"> 
          <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
           <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-310167"> 
           <div class="avatar">
            <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-head"> 
            <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
            <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">May 27, 2016 at 11:45 PM</span> 
            <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-310167" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
            <span class="edit"></span> 
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-310167"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Hi Jill,</p> 
             <p>There isn’t a website maker that I’m aware of that allows users to upload their own files into your website. You can probably create one by it will require a much more powerful, heavily customizable website maker (perhaps WordPress or something like that).</p> 
             <p>A work around is for you to list out your products, and after a customer purchases you can then send him/her an email providing further instructions on how they can send you their photos. I’d imagine you can use a website maker that allows you to sell digital products (so they don’t have to fill in a shipping address). </p> 
             <p>Once they have made a purchase, you can set up an automatic email that gets send to them right away, providing further instructions on how they can send you their photos. Website makers allow you to send “Thank You” emails after someone purchases from you – so just use this email to insert your instructions.</p> 
             <p>You can see which online store builder supports digital products <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/e-commerce-online-store-builders-comparison-chart/" target="_blank">here</a>. </p> 
             <p>Jeremy</p> 
            </div>

               <p>Hi Alexia,</p> 
               <p>All website builders should be offering the same tools and design templates for both US and Canada. I’m not aware that they limit tools / templates to users outside of the US, as Canada is a large market for most website builders.</p> 
               <p>As for cons of Squarespace and Shopify, you can view our reviews for them <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/squarespace-review/" target="_blank">here</a> and <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/shopify-reviews/" target="_blank">here</a>. We listed out certain pros and cons for each one of them there.</p>

           <div id="li-comment-310092" class="comment-container"> 
            <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
             <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-310092"> 
             <div class="avatar">
              <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">May 19, 2016 at 8:27 PM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-310092" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-310092"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hi Anni,</p> 
               <p>Website builders and (most technology services online) generally speaking, can shut down your account if you grossly violate their terms of services. Some examples may include posting adult content, hate content, that sort of content when you are not supposed to under their terms of services.</p> 
               <p>So if you’re worried, make sure you read through Wix’s terms of services / use (link at the bottom of the Wix site). One should always practice the same level of prudence for all other services you use online. I know most people can’t be bothered to read them, but it’s just being careful.</p> 
               <p>If you are just posting or selling fashion designs / products, I don’t see why they will shut you down. After all, Wix has over 1.9 million paying customers which tells you that they’re a very successful business so I’m sure they’re not going to “randomly” shut down “normal” websites!</p> 
               <p>Hope this helps.</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div> 
              <div class="reply"> 
               <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-310092" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-310092&quot;, &quot;310092&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a>

        <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor odd alt thread-even depth-1"> <a name="comment-309946"></a> 
         <div id="li-comment-309946" class="comment-container"> 
          <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
           <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-309946"> 
           <div class="avatar">
            <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-head"> 
            <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
            <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">May 5, 2016 at 6:46 PM</span> 
            <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-309946" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
            <span class="edit"></span> 
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-309946"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Hello Judy,</p> 
             <p>Sorry to hear about your WordPress site! Take a look at Weebly. It’s super easy to use and allows you to publish a site very quickly. </p> 
             <p>In addition to that, the reason why I’m suggesting Weebly (given you’re short of time) is that they give you access to edit the HTML / CSS codes so you can make custom tweaks to the design if you want to. It sounds like this is something you can take advantage of given you know how to work with codes and that your customer wants a customized design. The other website makers don’t give you as much access (or no access at all) to the codes of the website.</p> 
             <p>You can sell products with Weebly, and you can set up a membership area to hide some pages to the public. However, the membership functions are fairly basic, so make sure you review their support portal to see what’s possible. For instance, you can’t set up paid membership subscriptions (meaning your members are billed every month for joining). But you can definitely set up a membership gateway – you just can’t charge for it.</p> 
             <p>Hope this helps! And good luck!</p> 
             <p>Jeremy</p> 
            </div> 
            <div class="reply"> 
             <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-309946" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-309946&quot;, &quot;309946&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
            </div>

        <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor odd alt thread-even depth-1"> <a name="comment-309894"></a> 
         <div id="li-comment-309894" class="comment-container"> 
          <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
           <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-309894"> 
           <div class="avatar">
            <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-head"> 
            <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
            <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">May 1, 2016 at 9:23 PM</span> 
            <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-309894" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
            <span class="edit"></span> 
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-309894"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Hey Tanya,</p> 
             <p>Sounds pretty nerve wrecking to me! But honestly, I think a lot of businesses go through the same challenges: 1) to do it themselves or pay a lot of money to someone else to manage it; and 2) how to retain search engine ranking if you’ve been around for years (and rank well).</p> 
             <p>I think there are merits to paying someone to building the site and managing it for you – but ONLY if you have a proven business model that’s generating profits, which sounds like you do.</p> 
             <p>A lot of people are tempted to pay designers / developers a lot of money before they even have a viable, cash flowing business yet – it’s a big mistake in my view (<a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/why-you-should-not-hire-a-website-designer/" target="_blank">we wrote an article about that here</a>). I guess it’s easier to throw money at a problem (them not knowing how to build / design a website), when in fact, there are a lot of solutions to help business owners (such as the website makers we outlined above). </p> 
             <p>In your case, since you have an existing business already, you have options. Either to pay the team to build / manage for you, or do it yourself. It also sounds like you’re quite hands on, so it might make sense for you to use a website maker so you can add / remove / modify content yourself, without using a “middle person”, so to speak.</p> 
             <p>It seems to me that your bigger concern is how to build a new website without losing business (by retaining good search ranking). This is a bit of a “black box” as there is no guarantee that search engines will behave the same way once you have a new site up and running.</p> 
             <p>So what Google recommends is that you “301 redirect” your old webpage addresses to your new webpage addresses. If you do it correctly, Google will know that your pages from your existing / current website, are now part of the new website. So in theory, all your page rankings should be passed on to your new website. In theory, you wouldn’t lose any rankings in search engines. </p> 
             <p>However, in practice, it may potentially be different. So just keep that in mind. There are a lot of discussions about 301 redirects and case studies about moving websites on the internet – so do spend some time studying those.</p> 
             <p>As for how to move domain names, it’s not too challenging. Go to a domain name registrar (such as <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/go/godaddy" target="_blank">GoDaddy</a>) and you can purchase a domain migration service. They will have instructions on how you can move your domain name from your existing provider, and into GoDaddy. </p> 
             <p>You should technically own your domain name (but it depends on how you worked out your deal with your current service provider), so you should be able to transfer it into another domain name registrar (see our <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/what-is-a-domain-name-beginners-guide/" target="_blank">domain name guide – Topic 7</a>). If you meet resistance, perhaps don’t tell them you want to stop using them to service your entire website. Maybe tell them you only want to move the domain name. Once the domain name is out, then move on to the next phase. One step at a time.</p> 
             <p>I know it’s a daunting decision and process, so take your time in studying what others have done. Learn more about the domain migration process (and make sure you confirm with your current provider that you can move your domain name) and also the 301 redirect process.</p> 
             <p>Good luck!</p> 
             <p>Jeremy</p> 
            </div> 
            <div class="reply"> 
             <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-309894" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-309894&quot;, &quot;309894&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
            </div>

           <ul class="children"> 
            <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor odd alt depth-3"> <a name="comment-309943"></a> 
             <div id="li-comment-309943" class="comment-container"> 
              <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
               <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-309943"> 
               <div class="avatar">
                <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
               </div> 
               <div class="comment-head"> 
                <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
                <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">May 5, 2016 at 6:17 PM</span> 
                <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-309943" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
                <span class="edit"></span> 
               </div> 
               <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-309943"> 
                <div itemprop="text">
                 <p>Tanya,</p> 
                 <p>Yes. The top 3 website builders we discussed above all give you the ability to perform 301 re-directs. If you visit their support guides and type in “301” they will give you more details about how to do them.</p> 
                 <p>Their 301 re-directs only work if you use the SAME domain name as your previous site. If you are changing domain names (avoid this if possible, unless you want to rebrand your company), the process becomes a bit more tricky. </p> 
                 <p>Basically, you tell the website builder what are your old page URLs, and what are the new ones. So if your URL for a specific page doesn’t change after you migrate to a new website builder, then you don’t need to do a 301 re-direct for that specific URL.</p> 
                 <p>Migration is always a tricky task, especially if you have good search rankings to start out with. There are different known and unknown reasons why a search engine (such as Google) will change your ranking after a site migration. Keeping the URL structure the same for each page or doing 301 re-directs for those that changed is only one part of it. There are a lot of resources / discussions that cover this online, so a Google search will lead you to some of them!</p> 
                 <p>Jeremy</p> 
                </div> 
                <div class="reply"> 
                 <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-309943" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-309943&quot;, &quot;309943&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
                </div>

        <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor odd alt thread-even depth-1"> <a name="comment-309849"></a> 
         <div id="li-comment-309849" class="comment-container"> 
          <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
           <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-309849"> 
           <div class="avatar">
            <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-head"> 
            <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
            <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">April 28, 2016 at 6:49 PM</span> 
            <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-309849" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
            <span class="edit"></span> 
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-309849"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Hi Rick,</p> 
             <p>Correct – “X” means the website creator doesn’t offer that specific option. In the Quiz, the question asks if you want a mobile “friendly” website creator – which doesn’t necessarily mean it has to be a mobile responsive design. I’m sorry if it wasn’t clear enough!</p> 
             <p>Wix doesn’t offer mobile responsive designs at the moment, but they do offer you a dedicated mobile editor where you can customize the mobile version of your website. So technically, your website can show different layouts / content on mobile phones, than on desktop computers. </p> 
             <p>The advantage is that Wix allows you to pick and choose which content you want to display on a much smaller screen (mobile device) – so this gives you more control and flexibility. The drawback is that you have a bit more work to do to configure your mobile website.</p> 
             <p>With a mobile responsive design (where the desktop version of your website is automatically re-arranges itself to fit nicely into a mobile device), you don’t have to edit for a separate mobile website so it saves you a bit of time. The drawback, is that you don’t have control over your mobile display.</p> 
             <p>So just some pros and cons to consider for other readers who aren’t familiar with this.</p> 
             <p>We have a <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/mobile-editor-review-wix-weebly-squarespace-jimdo/" target="_blank">detailed discussion about mobile displays</a> for various website creators here.</p> 
             <p>Jeremy</p> 
            </div> 
            <div class="reply"> 
             <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-309849" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-309849&quot;, &quot;309849&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
            </div>

        <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor odd alt thread-even depth-1"> <a name="comment-309517"></a> 
         <div id="li-comment-309517" class="comment-container"> 
          <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
           <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-309517"> 
           <div class="avatar">
            <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-head"> 
            <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
            <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">April 4, 2016 at 9:30 AM</span> 
            <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-309517" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
            <span class="edit"></span> 
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-309517"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Jay,</p> 
             <p>Sometimes it’s challenging to look at a pre-set “out of the box” template and see if it works or not, as the layout of the content and the outline of the design “as is” might not be what you have in mind.</p> 
             <p>The benefit of using Wix (for instance) is that you can drag and drop content wherever you want. They also allow you to heavily customize the design of your webpages, without coding. So it might take some work, but you can alter the layout of the templates with their tools so to create what you have in mind. This applies to most other website makers out there (though it’s easier to alter designs with Wix). </p> 
             <p>Other than that, if you want a design that completely catered to what you have in mind, you can always hire a designer and coder to custom create a design for you. But I think that’s going a bit too far, if you don’t have a cash flowing business.</p> 
             <p>Jeremy</p> 
            </div> 
            <div class="reply"> 
             <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-309517" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-309517&quot;, &quot;309517&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
            </div> 
           </div> 
          </article> 
         </div> </li>

          <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor even depth-2"> <a name="comment-309474"></a> 
           <div id="li-comment-309474" class="comment-container"> 
            <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
             <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-309474"> 
             <div class="avatar">
              <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">March 31, 2016 at 6:25 PM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-309474" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-309474"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hey Indigo,</p> 
               <p>There isn’t a website builder that’s listed here that will give you all the tools you want – specifically the email subscription list and podcasting function. But they will be able to help you with your other requirements (pages, blogging, uploading YouTube, etc).</p> 
               <p>If podcasting is more important than email sign ups, then take a look at Squarespace as they have a built-in “native” <a href="https://support.squarespace.com/hc/en-us/articles/205814338" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">podcasting tool</a>. You can then add on a newsletter sign up widget such as Aweber to your website. That will work.</p> 
               <p>If having an integrated newsletter sign up function is more important to you, then look at Wix (<a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/go/wixshoutout" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Shoutout</a>) or Weebly (<a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/go/weeblypromote" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Promote</a>) as they have built in email subscription tools. You can integrate podcast audio sessions by inserting players like <a href="https://soundcloud.com/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Soundcloud</a> or something like that. </p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div> 
              <div class="reply"> 
               <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-309474" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-309474&quot;, &quot;309474&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
              </div> 
             </div> 
            </article>

        <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1"> <a name="comment-309449"></a> 
         <div id="li-comment-309449" class="comment-container"> 
          <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
           <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-309449"> 
           <div class="avatar">
            <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-head"> 
            <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
            <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">March 30, 2016 at 12:50 AM</span> 
            <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-309449" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
            <span class="edit"></span> 
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-309449"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Hi Cristina,</p> 
             <p>Ranking high in search engines based on just using images will probably be pretty tough, as Google (and probably other major search engines) might have a harder time understanding what your website is about if you only have images. It’s easier for them to “read” your text and understand what you’re discussing on the page.</p> 
             <p>Having said that, what you should do is make sure you insert “Alt Text” for all your images. This allows Google to understand what the image is about since they can’t “read” pictures yet. </p> 
             <p>Also, name your image files in a very specific way. So don’t name your image files generically, like “Image” for instance. If your image displays a Mac Air, then name the image file name to “Mac Air” or something like that. Be as specific as you can, as Google does assess the name of the file name when its trying to understand what the image file is about (not sure how much weigh they put on it, but it’s not a lot of work to label files anyway).</p> 
             <p>Further, do all the basic SEO stuff, like meta descriptions, titles on your page so search engines know what the page is all about. All the drag &amp; drop website creators above allow you to do that.</p> 
             <p>If you can insert written content, that would be best. Even just to describe what your page is all about. This will help search engines understand your page content.</p> 
             <p>Last but not least, try to promote your pages as much as you can. Share it with online communities, so get people talking and writing about your site. The more other websites link to your website / webpages, the higher it may rank in search results (generally speaking). Search engines view direct links to your website / webpages as an endorsement. We have a bit of information <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/frequently-asked-questions-website-builders/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">about SEO on our FAQ page here</a> – you might find it helpful as well.</p> 
             <p>Hope this helps!</p> 
             <p>Jeremy</p> 
            </div> 
            <div class="reply"> 
             <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-309449" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-309449&quot;, &quot;309449&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
            </div> 
           </div> 
          </article> 
         </div> </li>

         <ul class="children"> 
          <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor odd alt depth-2"> <a name="comment-309207"></a> 
           <div id="li-comment-309207" class="comment-container"> 
            <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
             <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-309207"> 
             <div class="avatar">
              <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">March 14, 2016 at 4:29 AM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-309207" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div>

           <div id="li-comment-308949" class="comment-container"> 
            <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
             <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-308949">

             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">February 25, 2016 at 7:55 PM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-308949" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-308949"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hi Lenushka,</p> 
               <p>Wix does have an app in their <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/go/wixapphome" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">App Market</a> that will allow you to collect payments in Bitcoin. Just search for “Bitcoin” in the search bar.</p> 
               <p>You can also consider Shopify or Bigcommerce, both of which are “pure” ecommerce builders and are some of the best online store platforms in the world right now. Both do have Bitcoin payment processing capabilities. Take a <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/e-commerce-online-store-builders-comparison-chart/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">look at this page</a> here to check them out.</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div>
