        <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1"> <a name="comment-308910"></a> 
         <div id="li-comment-308910" class="comment-container"> 
          <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
           <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-308910"> 
           <div class="avatar">
            <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-head"> 
            <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
            <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">February 24, 2016 at 12:17 AM</span> 
            <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-308910" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
            <span class="edit"></span> 
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-308910"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Hi D,</p> 
             <p>Weebly does offer a year of free domain, if you sign up to their annual plan (this is highlighted in our footnote and also on Weebly’s site I believe). </p> 
             <p>We also have a comprehensive discussion about domain names <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/what-is-a-domain-name-beginners-guide/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">in this article</a> here, where we discuss the pros and cons of receiving a domain name through a website creator (such as Weebly) or purchasing one from domain name registrars such as <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/go/godaddy" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">GoDaddy</a>.</p> 
             <p>The auto charging of credit card relates to the renewal of your premium plan. Most online services nowadays auto charge on a monthly or annual basis (depending on which plan you chose) and this is a standard practice. It’s the same as signing to a monthly / annual gym membership – they wont’ call / email you to notify you that they will bill you. </p> 
             <p>Businesses nowadays assume that if you don’t want to continue with their services, you’d contact them to cancel your plan. In this case, you just have to log into your Weebly user portal to discontinue your plan. This too, is a very standard procedure across all website creators (or other online services).</p> 
             <p>Sorry to hear about your disappointment though. I can understand that getting billed without expecting it is a very frustrating experience. However, it’s a very standard business practice, just like if you purchased a gym membership or a monthly subscription to a magazine. What I personally do, is set up calendar reminders of upcoming renewals of all my subscriptions, so that reminder gives me ample time to consider if I’d like to renew or not. If not, I contact the service provider to cancel.</p> 
             <p>Jeremy</p> 
            </div> 
            <div class="reply"> 
             <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-308910" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-308910&quot;, &quot;308910&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
            </div> 
           </div> 
          </article>

        <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1"> <a name="comment-308847"></a> 
         <div id="li-comment-308847" class="comment-container"> 
          <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
           <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-308847"> 
           <div class="avatar">
            <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/Logo-Avatar.png" width="40" height="40" alt="" class="avatar avatar-40wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo avatar-default">
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-head"> 
            <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Ellen</span> </span> 
            <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">February 20, 2016 at 8:46 AM</span> 
            <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-308847" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
            <span class="edit"></span> 
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-308847"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>I use Wix as my website builder 99% of the time and recommend to other people. My clients have been very impressed with their websites developed in Wix and people have commented on how professional my own website is which I developed with Wix. When my clients saw my website they asked me what platform I used and when I told them they wanted me to create their website right away for them. </p> 
             <p>I have also worked with GoDaddy and WordPress. I still always end up going back to Wix. I find that Wix offers an abundance of features to create and build a professional website. Creating and building a website with GoDaddy was okay but I found that there were many limitations as to what I could do to ‘dress up’ the website, e.g. headers, slideshows, videos, include apps, etc. </p> 
             <p>WordPress also helps to produce very dynamic websites if someone prefers to use WordPress. I guess I just find Wix is easier to work with.</p> 
            </div> 
            <div class="reply"> 
             <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-308847" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-308847&quot;, &quot;308847&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Ellen">Reply</a>

         <ul class="children"> 
          <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor odd alt depth-2"> <a name="comment-308750"></a> 
           <div id="li-comment-308750" class="comment-container"> 
            <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
             <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-308750"> 
             <div class="avatar">
              <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">February 15, 2016 at 5:01 PM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-308750" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-308750"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hey Drue,</p> 
               <p>Wix and Weebly both have membership gateway functions (see Footnote 16 above). However, neither has a payment gateway integrated with it. So while you can create membership areas with both web builders, you can’t charge your members for access (yet).</p> 
               <p>If that becomes important to you, there are membership widgets such as Sentry Login that can be used with Wix and Weebly. Hope this points you in the right direction!</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div> 
              <div class="reply"> 
               <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-308750" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-308750&quot;, &quot;308750&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
              </div> 
             </div> 
            </article> 
           </div> </li> 
         </ul> </li>

            <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-308619" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span>

           </div> 
           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-308619"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Hello, Thank you for the great info. Just a correction, Weebly does not offer a free domain. In fact, you pay a whopping $40 USD for a single domain through Weebly. Then they make you get your email address through Google Apps for another whopping $45 USD. Also, they do not notify customers of charges to their credit cards. Not even a courtesy email receipt. I once was a happy Weebly customer. I’m super turned off and will be closing out all of my sites and re-building elsewhere.</p> 
            </div>

             <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-308543"> 
             <div class="avatar">
              <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">

             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">February 3, 2016 at 4:46 PM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-308543" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-308543"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hello Larry,</p> 
               <p>I personally use <a href="https://apps.google.com/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Google Business Apps</a> to create custom email addresses, and it’s about $5 per month, so marginally more expensive than GoDaddy.</p> 
               <p>Note that Wix is <a href="http://www.wix.com/about/mailboxes" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">partnered</a> with Google Business Apps, so the set up is probably pretty easy.</p> 
               <p>I personally prefer the Gmail user interface and its reliability. Having said that, I haven’t used GoDaddy’s email service before. So I guess it depends on which one you are more comfortable with.</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div>

             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-308836"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>You can have Go Daddy forward pretty much any email address with a domain name you purchase there to another email address. That way you don’t have to actually purchase the email addresses until you’re ready. Worked really well for us. We have three email addresses for one domain name that are forwarded to a Go Daddy email address at an entirely different domain we own. Hope that helps.</p> 
              </div>

           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-308496"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Hello Oliver,</p> 
             <p>I think either one (Wix or Squarespace) works. It sounds to me that you’re aware of the pros and cons of using Wix and Squarespace. We do have an <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wix-vs-squarespace-comparison-chart/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">article here</a> that compares both website creators directly here.</p> 
             <p>If you’re a bit torn about which one to use, I’d suggest that you sign up with both platforms and just invest a few hours to play with them. You might end up loving one of them over the other! It’s like test driving a car. You might think you like a car, until test driving it.</p> 
             <p>Hope this helps!</p> 
             <p>Jeremy</p>

          <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor even depth-2"> <a name="comment-308494"></a> 
           <div id="li-comment-308494" class="comment-container"> 
            <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
             <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-308494"> 
             <div class="avatar">
              <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">February 1, 2016 at 4:23 PM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-308494" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-308494"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Thanks, Chris.</p> 
               <p>I don’t think Wix has any specific real estate / property searching tools. </p> 
               <p>The way you can integrate non-Wix widgets into a Wix website is to use the “HTML Code” function, where you can embed the codes from the widget provider. </p> 
               <p>So visit your real estate tool provider and see if they allow you to embed codes on websites to make them work (I’d be surprised if they don’t), and just sign up to a Wix account and give that a try to see if it works well for you!</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div> 
              <div class="reply"> 
               <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-308494" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-308494&quot;, &quot;308494&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
              </div>

          <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor even depth-2"> <a name="comment-308434"></a> 
           <div id="li-comment-308434" class="comment-container"> 
            <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

             </div> 
             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">January 29, 2016 at 3:16 PM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-308434" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-308434"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>hi Joe,</p> 
               <p>Take a look at Wix or Weebly. Both will allow you to post unlimited number of pictures, videos and can link up to PayPal to help you process payments.</p> 
               <p>Both are quite easy to use, but I’d say Weebly is easier than Wix as they have less bells and whistles. </p> 
               <p>You can sign up to both for free, and give them a try. No obligations to sign up to a paying plan at all, until you’re happy with your final choice.</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div>

             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span>

              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-308312" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-308312"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hi Mark,</p> 
               <p>Yes you can definitely connect a .ca domain name to any of the website builders above (such as Wix or Squarespace).</p> 
               <p>They may not sell a .ca domain name, but you can purchase one from a domain name registrar (such as <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/go/godaddy" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">GoDaddy</a> or <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/go/namecheap" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Namecheap</a>), then connect the domain name to the website you build.</p> 
               <p>Take a look at our <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/what-is-a-domain-name-beginners-guide/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Guide to Domain Names</a> for more details!</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div>

               <p>Hi John,</p> 
               <p>I’m not entirely sure if that’s how education websites or Udemy work? I “think” you build your entire course through Udemy so that’s quite different than on your website? So I’m not quite sure if you can just take your website and throw it into Udemy.</p> 
               <p>But what you can do is advertise your courses on your website, and link / lead people to Udemy (or other educational platforms) so they can sign up there. Either Wix or Weebly will allow you to build content around your courses and link out to wherever you sell your courses.</p>

             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-308043"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hi Cathy,</p> 
               <p>I’d recommend that you use Wix (<a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wix-review/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">see our review here</a> if you haven’t yet).</p> 
               <p>They have an in-house booking engine (called Wix Bookings) that allow your visitors to book and pay for appointments directly on your website. The booking engine will also notify your clients of the appointment. Take a look a this video to <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8qBThQ8JUtg" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">see how Wix Bookings works</a>. </p> 
               <p>Wix also allosw you to insert downloadable files (for your forms), and also embed videos and affiliate links.</p> 
               <p>Hope this helps!</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div>

        <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1"> <a name="comment-307964"></a> 
         <div id="li-comment-307964" class="comment-container"> 
          <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
           <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-307964"> 
           <div class="avatar">
            <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-head"> 
            <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
            <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">January 4, 2016 at 2:16 PM</span> 
            <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-307964" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
            <span class="edit"></span> 
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-307964"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Hi Gary,</p> 
             <p>Thanks for your comment. I actually don’t entirely agree with your observation, but I can understand why one may prefer a responsive design.</p> 
             <p>Wix allows you to build a mobile friendly site with its mobile editor where you actually get to pick and choose what you display on your mobile site. So it is just as effective as a website with a responsive template. </p> 
             <p>The key point is to present your website in a user / viewing friendly way, and Wix (as well as other responsive designs) can help you accomplish that.</p> 
             <p>For some other website makers that offer responsive templates, even though the website will display well on mobile devices, you have no control over how the site will be displayed (unless you edit the codes to the template). With Wix, you get a certain level of control via its mobile editor. The drawback, is that you do have to do a bit more work to edit your site in the mobile editor but I think the trade off for the additional control / flexibility is well worth it.</p> 
             <p>A lot of very large companies out there don’t use responsive designs either. They have a dedicated mobile site so they can control their visitors’ user experience. </p> 
             <p>So while responsive design is a pretty hot topic nowadays, it is just an option or a tool. I wouldn’t suggest getting too caught up in the “hype” and focus on what can get the job done based on what you need!</p> 
             <p>Thanks for raising this point, Gary – it’s definitely an interesting discussion for all of our readers!</p> 
             <p>Jeremy</p> 
            </div> 
            <div class="reply"> 
             <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-307964" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-307964&quot;, &quot;307964&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
            </div> 
           </div> 
          </article> 
         </div>

                 <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-308225"> 
                  <div itemprop="text">
                   <p>Jeremy there are a couple of options – you can always go down the WP route with Woo or Easy Digital Downloads plus a good theme like Marketify, but the latest and greatest thing around for my money is sharetribe (and no, I am not affiliated with them in any way). It’s a clever and user-friendly marketplace builder. Custom domains are possible on most plans, and price wise pretty reasonable (starting at US39/mo for up to 300 members). It’s clean and crisp, and functionality is high with good support. Pretty much what Squarespace would look like in a marketplace offering.</p>

        <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1"> <a name="comment-307927"></a> 
         <div id="li-comment-307927" class="comment-container"> 
          <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
           <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-307927"> 
           <div class="avatar">
            <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-head"> 
            <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
            <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">January 1, 2016 at 12:37 PM</span> 
            <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-307927" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
            <span class="edit"></span> 
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-307927"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Hi Richard,</p> 
             <p>The statistics above (websites powered by each platform) are publicly disclosed figures from the website makers. Further, Wix is a publicly traded company so their disclosed statistics are audited every year, and reviewed / verified to a certain extent on a quarterly basis. </p> 
             <p>Based on their most recent quarterly statistics, they have over 1.6 million PAID users. So that is a meaningful number. Unfortunately, as other web builders are not publicly listed on the stock exchange (yet), there isn’t a way to find out how many actual paid users they have.</p> 
             <p>Another metric we like is how frequently they are searched on Google. <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wix-vs-weebly-vs-squarespace-vs-jimdo/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">We have a chart here</a> that shows you the trending of Google searches, which will give a bit of a taste of how popular they are compared to each other. It’s not a perfect metric, but when combined with several other data points, can start to help you form a view of which website maker is leading the industry.</p> 
             <p>It seems to me that W3Techs (the source you quoted) is based on surveys. So there can be a lot of biases in their studies. But I guess they’ve formulated their table based on the best available stats they could collect.</p> 
             <p>At the end of the day, it’s hard to assess with pinpoint accuracy who has the most active users given limited data. The best metric I think is the number of paid users. But as mentioned, only Wix discloses this data, at the moment.</p> 
             <p>Thanks for adding to this discussion!</p> 
             <p>Jeremy</p> 
            </div> 
            <div class="reply"> 
             <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-307927" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-307927&quot;, &quot;307927&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
            </div> 
           </div> 
          </article>

          <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor even depth-2"> <a name="comment-307929"></a> 
           <div id="li-comment-307929" class="comment-container"> 
            <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
             <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-307929"> 
             <div class="avatar">
              <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">January 1, 2016 at 12:48 PM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-307929" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-307929"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hi Nik,</p> 
               <p>I don’t think Wix (or any of the website builder above) will be able to cater to your needs. Wix and Weebly have built in membership tools, but they’re limited to allowing each member to sign in with their own user name and password to access certain membership protected pages. </p> 
               <p>So if you want anything more advanced than that, such as creating a paid gateway for paying members only, or being able to customize the database on the backend, you might have to use something like WordPress.</p> 
               <p>But have a look at Sentry Login, which is a membership widget that can work with Wix to help you create a paid membership site. They might also have more flexibility on the backend so you can customize a few things there.</p> 
               <p>Happy New Year! </p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div> 
              <div class="reply"> 
               <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-307929" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-307929&quot;, &quot;307929&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a>

             <p>Jeremy, I run a soccer club that is in urgent need of a new website and am wondering if any of these free tools will work for me.          <ul class="children"> 
          <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor odd alt depth-2"> <a name="comment-307898"></a> 
           <div id="li-comment-307898" class="comment-container"> 
            <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
             <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-307898"> 
             <div class="avatar">
              <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">December 30, 2015 at 10:55 AM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-307898" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-307898"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hi Peter,</p> 
               <p>I think given the complexity of your website needs, it’s best to consider hiring someone to guide you through the process especially if you don’t have technical / coding skills.</p> 
               <p>While some of the drag &amp; drop website builders can cater to some of the items you need (such as selling merchandises, multi-level menu, newsletters, social sharing), some of the more advanced features are beyond the basic capabilities of the web builders (pulling in content, segmenting user capabilities, creating multiple admin users).</p> 
               <p><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/how-much-should-a-website-cost/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Have a look at this article</a> here to get a better sense of how much it might potentially cost you if you were to consider building a custom site with developers assisting you.</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div> 
              <div class="reply"> 
               <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-307898" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-307898&quot;, &quot;307898&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a>

           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-307858"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>WIX is a good site, I have my Travel Agency site built with WIX, but the down side is that you can not add an SSL certificate with them.</p> 
            </div> 
            <div class="reply"> 
             <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-307858" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-307858&quot;, &quot;307858&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Randy">Reply</a>

         <ul class="children"> 
          <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor odd alt depth-2"> <a name="comment-307868"></a> 
           <div id="li-comment-307868" class="comment-container"> 
            <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
             <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-307868"> 
             <div class="avatar">
              <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">December 28, 2015 at 10:41 AM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-307868" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-307868"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Thanks for your comment, Randy.</p> 
               <p>With Wix (or any other drag &amp; drop website builders) above, you won’t be able to add SSL certificates to all the webpages. But if you are using their ecommerce tools, the check out cart will include SSL so that all your purchasing customers’ private information is secure. </p> 
               <p>Generally speaking, some website owners like to add SSL certificates to every single webpage on their site. Google said that one of their many ranking factors (estimated to be well over 200 factors) is whether your site has an SSL certificate, but all the studies I’ve seen from leading experts indicate that this ranking factor is not meaningful to how a website ranks in search engines (yet anyway). </p> 
               <p>It’s an interesting topic of discussion so thanks for raising it!</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div> 
              <div class="reply"> 
               <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-307868" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-307868&quot;, &quot;307868&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
              </div> 
             </div> 
            </article> 
           </div> </li> 
         </ul> </li> 
        <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1"> <a name="comment-307814"></a> 
         <div id="li-comment-307814" class="comment-container"> 
          <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
           <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-307814"> 
           <div class="avatar">
            <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-head"> 
            <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
            <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">December 23, 2015 at 12:22 PM</span> 
            <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-307814" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
            <span class="edit"></span> 
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-307814"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Hi Jesse,</p> 
             <p>You’re very welcome and glad our discussions here have been helpful to you!</p> 
             <p>In terms of domain names, you can find decent deals at reputable domain name registrars <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/go/godaddy" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">such as GoDaddy</a>.</p> 
             <p>As for connecting a custom domain name (your own domain name) to a website, for most website creators (if not all), you will have to upgrade to a paid subscription plan. So for Weebly, you will have to subscribe to at least their Starter plan. </p> 
             <p>If you sign up to the Starter Plan, you will only get a 1 year free domain name from Weebly if you subscribe to an annual plan. So if you sign up to the 6 months plan (which is the lowest period you can commit to for Weebly), you won’t get the free domain. </p> 
             <p>If you do get the annual plan (with the free domain), after the first free year, you will have to renew it every year after that for $20. If you purchase your own domain name (such as from GoDaddy), the average cost for a domain name is about $10 – $15 per year. </p> 
             <p>So you can weigh your pros and cons there (sign up with a web builder for 1 whole year and get the first year of domain name fee waived, or don’t commit as long and just buy your own domain name elsewhere, but know that you will pay a lower domain name fee every year afterwards).</p> 
             <p>As for PayPal, with Weebly specifically, you can only connect it to your shopping cart if you subscribe to their Business plan. The only payment processor that you can use with Weebly’s Starter plan, is Stripe (which is quite popular). But Stripe is not offered to every country around the world (you can see <a href="https://stripe.com/global" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">where they are available</a> here).</p> 
             <p>For your clothing / apparel store, aside from Weebly, <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/shopify-reviews/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">take a look at Shopify</a>. They’re a full-featured, pure online store builder. They’re not the cheapest, but for good reasons as they’re really good.</p> 
             <p>Take a look at our <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/e-commerce-online-store-builders-comparison-chart/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">ecommerce builder comparison chart here</a>.</p> 
             <p>Hope this helps!</p> 
             <p>Jeremy</p> 
             <p><em>[UPDATE: see our <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/what-is-a-domain-name-beginners-guide/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Beginners Guide to Domain Names</a> for more discussions on commonly asked questions about domain names]</em></p> 
            </div> 
            <div class="reply"> 
             <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-307814" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-307814&quot;, &quot;307814&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
            </div> 
           </div> 
          </article> 
         </div> </li>

        <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1"> <a name="comment-307722"></a> 
         <div id="li-comment-307722" class="comment-container"> 
          <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
           <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-307722"> 
           <div class="avatar">
            <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-head"> 
            <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
            <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">December 16, 2015 at 1:38 PM</span> 
            <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-307722" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
            <span class="edit"></span> 
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-307722"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Hi Joan,</p> 
             <p>That is very awkward for sure. I’m not sure why they should ask for your drivers license. All of the website makers that we’ve used before don’t ask for credit card information up front – only when you want to upgrade. I think nowadays, most services offer a free trial period first before asking for credit card information. </p> 
             <p>But that is not always the case as I’ve seen some businesses only allow people to try their products after they provide CC information – to isolate serious candidates. But those businesses are more specialized and are at a much higher price point (mainly business-to-business types of operations).</p> 
             <p>I would be very cautious when online businesses ask for drivers license. Something just doesn’t feel right. Did you ask them why they’d need that piece of information? I’d be very skeptical if their answer is “to verify that you are the holder of the credit card”. </p> 
             <p>Jeremy</p> 
            </div> 
            <div class="reply"> 
             <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-307722" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-307722&quot;, &quot;307722&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a>

         <ul class="children"> 
          <li class="comment odd alt depth-2"> <a name="comment-317525"></a> 
           <div id="li-comment-317525" class="comment-container"> 
            <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
             <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-317525"> 
             <div class="avatar">
              <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/Logo-Avatar.png" width="40" height="40" alt="" class="avatar avatar-40wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo avatar-default">
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Chris</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">September 18, 2017 at 8:28 PM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-317525" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-317525"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>As the director of online sales for a major automotive company, I can verify that requiring a scan of your driver’s license along with a scan of the credit card you are using is a common practice to prevent fraud on large ticket items. It is a protection for the merchant to verify that the consumer actually has the card in hand and that the name on the license matches the name on the credit card. Our company has been doing this for several years and it has decreased fraudulent purchases by a huge percentage. It is also a protection for the consumer to verify that a scammer is not using their stolen credit card number. If a consumer does not want to supply this information at purchase, we either cancel the transaction or give them the option of an alternative payment method.</p> 
              </div> 
              <div class="reply"> 
               <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-317525" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-317525&quot;, &quot;317525&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Chris">Reply</a> 
              </div> 
             </div> 
            </article> 
           </div>

                <div itemprop="text">
                 <p>Hi Chris,</p> 
                 <p>Thanks for adding to the discussion.</p> 
                 <p>It’s an interesting debate, that’s for sure – companies require personal information to verify legitimate users…yet users are wary of handing over very personal financial information to a company they’ve only just started working with, have never met and only have a virtual point of contact with. I’m sure you can see why people get concerned.</p> 
                 <p>Hopefully your insights go some way to clarifying why certain website builders require personal data up front. </p> 
                 <p>Thanks for contributing,<br> – Tom</p>

         <ul class="children"> 
          <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor odd alt depth-2"> <a name="comment-307687"></a> 
           <div id="li-comment-307687" class="comment-container"> 
            <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
             <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-307687"> 
             <div class="avatar">
              <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">December 14, 2015 at 2:02 PM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-307687" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-307687"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hello Kimberly,</p> 
               <p>I think all of the sites discussed above will work. If you don’t have a preference based on the discussion above, <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/quiz/start/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">take our Quiz</a> to see if it helps.</p> 
               <p>Or else I’d suggest you sign up to test out Wix, Squarespace and Weebly. Give them a free trial and see which on you prefer to work with. All of them are relatively easy to use (drag &amp; drop website builders), but their user interfaces are different. So you might prefer one over the others.</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div> 
              <div class="reply"> 
               <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-307687" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-307687&quot;, &quot;307687&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a>

             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-307685"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hello Marianne,</p> 
               <p>WordPress could definitely be frustrating for people who aren’t technical or haven’t learned it before. Most people (like yourself) just want to get the website built and move on to other important things!</p> 
               <p>I definitely recommend that you take a look at Wix. Wix has templates and tools that are directly relevant to hotel / B&amp; B type websites. Their tools allow your visitors to book rooms, and you can manage your booking calendar as well.</p> 
               <p><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/how-to-build-bed-and-breakfast-hotel-website/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Take a look at our discussion here</a> for more information.</p> 
               <p>Good luck!</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p>

         <ul class="children"> 
          <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor odd alt depth-2"> <a name="comment-307624"></a> 
           <div id="li-comment-307624" class="comment-container"> 
            <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
             <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-307624"> 
             <div class="avatar">
              <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">December 11, 2015 at 12:15 PM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-307624" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-307624"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hi Sandy,</p> 
               <p>It’s not “ridiculous” at all! A lot of websites are not funded and are built by volunteers.</p> 
               <p>Take a look at Wix or Weebly. Both allow you to publish a website for free. The only drawback is that you won’t be able to connect your own custom domain name (website address) to the website. You will have to use their subdomain name structure, so it will look something like abc.wix.com or abc.weebly.com</p> 
               <p>You also won’t get access to some more advanced tools. But you’ll get all the basic web building tools for free. </p> 
               <p>There is no time limit to how long you can use the free plan either. So if you decide to upgrade down the road, you have that option.</p> 
               <p>Hope this helps!</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div> 
              <div class="reply"> 
               <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-307624" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-307624&quot;, &quot;307624&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
              </div> 
             </div> 
            </article> 
           </div> </li> 
         </ul> </li>

              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-307474" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-307474"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hi Vickie,</p> 
               <p>Yes you can do that with Wix. Go to <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/go/wixapp" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Wix’s App Store</a> and search for “Google Drive Share Tool”. You can display a Google Doc directly on your page so your visitors can view it.</p> 
               <p>However, this does require you to use a Google Doc (which is very similar to Microsoft Word).</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div>

           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-307321"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Hi Suchitra,</p> 
             <p>The website creators being compared here are drag &amp; drop website creators. WordPress is not a drag and drop platform and as such, it is not quite comparable to the ones being discussed here.</p> 
             <p>But we do have a series of <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/category/wordpress/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">comparison articles that you can find here</a>, where we benchmarked the drag and drop website creators to WordPress. Hopefully you’ll find them helpful.</p>

        <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1"> <a name="comment-306895"></a> 
         <div id="li-comment-306895" class="comment-container"> 
          <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
           <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-306895"> 
           <div class="avatar">

           </div> 
           <div class="comment-head"> 
            <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
            <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">November 23, 2015 at 1:10 PM</span> 
            <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-306895" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
            <span class="edit"></span> 
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-306895"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Hi James,</p> 
             <p>I haven’t seen an ecommerce website maker that allows a shopper to see the updates “live”. A lot of them can certainly allow a shopper to choose product variations. I know what you’re looking for though, as I’ve seen them with larger brands before (such as customizing a car with options online). </p> 
             <p>A workaround (though not as “cool”) will be to upload different pictures of various variations of your products, so shoppers can have a sense of what they can expect. Of course, the shopper may not find exactly the configuration that he/she wants.</p> 
             <p>All of the <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/e-commerce-online-store-builders-comparison-chart/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">ecommerce builders we’ve discussed here</a> will offer product variants (but no visual customizations), accepts credit cards / PayPal and offers shipping options.</p> 
             <p>Jeremy</p> 
            </div> 
            <div class="reply"> 
             <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-306895" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-306895&quot;, &quot;306895&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
            </div> 
           </div> 
          </article> 
         </div> </li>

          <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor odd alt depth-2"> <a name="comment-306827"></a> 
           <div id="li-comment-306827" class="comment-container"> 
            <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
             <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-306827"> 
             <div class="avatar">
              <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">

              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">November 21, 2015 at 1:51 PM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-306827" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-306827"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hi Cindy,</p> 
               <p>Refer to my comment on October 25 2015 below. PayPal has donation buttons that you can insert into your website builder. But if you want a website builder that offers a specific donation function, Squarespace has it.</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p>

        <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor even thread-even depth-1"> <a name="comment-306682"></a> 
         <div id="li-comment-306682" class="comment-container"> 
          <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
           <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-306682"> 
           <div class="avatar">
            <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-head"> 
            <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
            <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">November 18, 2015 at 6:37 AM</span> 
            <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-306682" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
            <span class="edit"></span> 
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-306682"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Hey John,</p> 
             <p>I think any one of the top website creators listed above will do the trick. They are all code free, drag and drop website creators so you don’t have to write any codes whatsoever. </p> 
             <p>Just insert two text or image elements to insert your words “actor” and “voice over”, then hyperlink them to two separate pages where you can insert videos or audio files. It’s really quite straightforward even for beginners! </p> 
             <p>Best thing to do is sign up for a couple of free trial accounts and start testing them out (such as Wix, Squarespace, Weebly). You might like one builder over the others, so it’s important to invest a little bit of time to see which one you prefer, before finalizing your decision.</p> 
             <p>Hope this points you in the right direction!</p> 
             <p>Jeremy</p> 
            </div>

It deals in custom order pens and has many different variations on what can be ordered.          <ul class="children"> 
          <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor odd alt depth-2"> <a name="comment-306115"></a> 
           <div id="li-comment-306115" class="comment-container"> 
            <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
             <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-306115"> 
             <div class="avatar">
              <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">November 6, 2015 at 11:34 AM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-306115" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-306115"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hi Logan,</p> 
               <p>If you want to build a straight forward ecommerce website, without a whole lot of advanced tools, then Wix, Weebly or Squarespace can work for you. If you want a lot of advanced bells and whistles in terms of tools, then pure ecommerce builders such as <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/bigcommerce-vs-shopify/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Shopify or Bigcommerce</a> might be more suitable.</p> 
               <p>With Wix, Weebly and Squarespace, you can list a lot of products and have multiple variations for each product (so you can sell a version of a pen that has different variations of colors, for instance). </p> 
               <p>My comments to your question is quite generic but that is based on limited information. I think the way forward is for you to just go through each builders’ website and study their ecommerce features. Also dive into their support pages to see what they are capable of doing.<br> You should also sign up to their free / trial accounts and invest some time to testing their builders – this is the best way to get an idea of whether you like using them or not!</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div> 
              <div class="reply"> 
               <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-306115" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-306115&quot;, &quot;306115&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
              </div> 
             </div> 
            </article> 
           </div> </li> 
         </ul> </li>

            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Thanks Jeremy and Connie, for a very helpful site and service, based on your own actual experience. : )</p> 
             <p>I want to build a website and/or blog that will basically be like a Facebook group. Members, posts, personal chats (PM), uploading photos, avatars, etc. I’d also like it to be password activated, meaning that people need a password that I provide to participate, and that can be changed – by me – periodically. I’d like also to have a payment feature available, and the ability to have other editors/admins/mods. I’d like to be able to have multiple groups with different passwords, and give members the ability to form their own groups, although that’s optional, since they could just ask me to do that.</p> 
             <p>I basically want to make a FB group outside of FB. Not to compete with them on any kind of scale, but just to provide a safer place for an existing group to be active. Safety and ID security are essential.</p> 
             <p>I’m willing to pay a modest monthly fee – $20-30, maybe even $50 or more (eventually!).</p> 
             <p>What do you suggest? Thanks in advance. : )</p>

             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-306109"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hi Vernon,</p> 
               <p>Thanks for your question. Unfortunately if you want to create a social interaction platform, you will need to hire a whole team of very advanced developers to help you do that – and that will not be cheap!</p> 
               <p>But it sounds to me that you might not want to build an entire social platform, but perhaps you are just looking for something outside of Facebook to use? If so, take a look at Ning.com. They are a tool which allows you to build your own community and might be helpful to you.</p> 
               <p>Hope this points you in the right direction!</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div>

            <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-306020" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
            <span class="edit"></span> 
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-306020"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Hi Songtu,</p> 
             <p>That’s a pretty hard question to answer, as it depends on a lot of different factors. </p> 
             <p>But if you just want to set up a basic website that describes what you are doing, contact information, product offerings / options, then any one of the above website creators will work well for you.</p> 
             <p>But if you want to allow people to log into a membership gateway and place private orders, with each order having its own characteristics / pricing terms, then I’d suggest you hire a capable developer to help you build a custom platform for that.</p> 
             <p>Jeremy</p> 
            </div> 
            <div class="reply"> 
             <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-306020" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-306020&quot;, &quot;306020&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a>

           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-305957">

I can’t seem to find a theme that really speaks to me on any of these builder sites. Do you know if any of these 3 would favor healthcare or consulting? I am leaning toward squarespace for the free trial, responsive themes, and website export option.<br> Thanks,<br> Will</p>

         <ul class="children"> 
          <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor even depth-2"> <a name="comment-306015"></a> 
           <div id="li-comment-306015" class="comment-container"> 
            <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
             <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-306015"> 
             <div class="avatar">
              <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">November 4, 2015 at 1:52 PM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-306015" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-306015"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hi Will,</p> 
               <p>All three builders have free options for you to test out. But if mobile responsive design is an important option for you, Weebly also has some new themes that are responsive. Weebly also allows you to export your website, but they are exported in raw HTML / CSS format so you can’t quite import it into another website builder platform (such as WordPress).</p> 
               <p>If you’re still undecided, one thing I’d highly recommend is to sign up to free accounts with each one of the platforms, and invest a few hours to “play” around with each website builder. Understanding what features are available for each platform’s is one thing, but you also have to enjoy working with the platform!</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div> 
              <div class="reply"> 
               <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-306015" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-306015&quot;, &quot;306015&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
              </div> 
             </div> 
            </article> 
           </div> </li> 
         </ul> </li>

             <p>Hi Jeremy,<br> I have a tiny hobby business with many low-priced items for sale.<br> I’m currently with jimdo @$240/yr which is pretty much absorbing my small profits &amp; looking to move to a lower-priced e-commerce website.<br> I suppose I’ll have to repost everything which took me weeks to do a couple years ago.<br> Could you please suggest the best of the above-mentioned websites for my hobby business longer term?<br> I mostly sell through the odd pop up shop, not online, very little online, though online is ultimately the way I want to go.<br> Unfortunately, I get very little traffic.<br> Your advice would be greatly appreciated.<br> Thank you!</p>

         <ul class="children"> 
          <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor even depth-2"> <a name="comment-305940"></a> 
           <div id="li-comment-305940" class="comment-container"> 
            <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
             <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-305940"> 
             <div class="avatar">
              <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">November 2, 2015 at 4:06 PM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-305940" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-305940"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hello Fran,</p> 
               <p>Have you considered downgrading your Jimdo plan to a lower plan (the Pro plan)? That way, you don’t have to migrate website builders and you get to cut your annual fees by more than half.</p> 
               <p>The challenge is that you mentioned that you have a lot of products to sell, and for all the website builders above, if you want to use their lower priced plans, they limit you to smaller number of products that you can sell.</p> 
               <p>With Weebly, you can sell up to 10 or 25 products with their Starter or Pro plans, respectively. With Squarespace, you can only sell 1 or 20 products with their Personal and Business plans. If you want to sell more products, then you’ll have to sign up to their highest plans, which won’t give you cost savings which is one of your goals.</p> 
               <p>So that’s the dilemma. If you want to list more products, you’ll need a higher plan. If you want a lower priced plan, you can’t list as many products. </p> 
               <p>One option is to consider trimming down your product offering to include only your best selling products. Just focus on those, and you might be able to choose a lower priced plan.</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div> 
              <div class="reply"> 
               <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-305940" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-305940&quot;, &quot;305940&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
              </div> 
             </div> 
            </article> 
           </div>

                 <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-306242"> 
                  <div itemprop="text">
                   <p>Hello Fran,</p> 
                   <p>Shopify’s lower plans are pretty reasonable, given that they are a pure ecommerce website builder and their tools are very advanced. If you are considering them, you don’t necessarily have to dive into their higher priced plan right away. Start with the lower plans and see if they help you grow your business. If they do, then you can consider if you want to invest in a higher plan to access even more tools. You can see <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/shopify-reviews/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">our review of Shopify</a> here.</p> 
                   <p>One thing to know is that Shopify can help you build a decent <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/how-to-set-up-a-facebook-store/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Facebook store</a>. Just something to consider since you mentioned you are using Facebook to grow your business.</p> 
                   <p>Jeremy</p>

        <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1"> <a name="comment-305700"></a> 
         <div id="li-comment-305700" class="comment-container"> 
          <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
           <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-305700"> 
           <div class="avatar">
            <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-head"> 
            <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
            <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">October 26, 2015 at 10:51 AM</span> 
            <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-305700" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
            <span class="edit"></span> 
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-305700"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Hi Johan,</p> 
             <p>The platforms that you referenced (except for WordPress) are geared towards photography websites, so the focus is a bit narrow for this chart. We do have a discussion <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/photoshelter-review/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">article about PhotoShelter</a> here.</p> 
             <p>As for WordPress.org, it is a CMS (content management system) and is different from the drag &amp; drop website makers we are comparing here. With WordPress.org, you can’t drag and drop, or move content around without knowing how to code. Also, you need to set up your own hosting which can be technically challenging. </p> 
             <p>The website makers we discussed above do not require you to know how to code or set up your own hosting services. They’re very user friendly and are targeting users who are not technical, or those who don’t want to spend excessive amounts of time managing the technical aspects of website building.</p> 
             <p>We’ve considered WordPress.com (the hosted version of WordPress which is less technical than WordPress.org), but it is not a drag and drop set up. As such, this makes it challenging to customize your design and layout.</p> 
             <p>Hope this explains things a bit.</p> 
             <p>Jeremy</p> 
            </div> 
            <div class="reply"> 
             <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-305700" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-305700&quot;, &quot;305700&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
            </div> 
           </div> 
          </article>

             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-305578"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hey Bram,</p> 
               <p>None of the website builders compared here have a “Done For You” type of services, as their intent is to enable you to build websites without having to know how to code. So they are based on a “Do It Yourself” model.</p> 
               <p>But you can always hire capable designers to help you build your website. For instance, Squarespace has a listing of <a href="http://specialists.squarespace.com/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">designers, developers and set up experts</a> that you can hire to help you out. They’re not a part of Squarespace, but they are listed on their website.</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div>

        <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1"> <a name="comment-305509"></a> 
         <div id="li-comment-305509" class="comment-container"> 
          <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
           <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-305509"> 
           <div class="avatar">
            <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-head"> 
            <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
            <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">October 20, 2015 at 7:12 PM</span> 
            <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-305509" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
            <span class="edit"></span> 
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-305509"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Hi Geoffrey, </p> 
             <p>If you want a platform that allows you to control or store data (such as contact information), you’ll probably need to find a more powerful solution, such as a CRM (customer relationship management tool), which can be costly. But if you don’t mind updating a database manually, Excel spreadsheet is a very handy way to do so. This just means you won’t be able to integrate your Excel database with your website, which should be fine for smaller operations. But if you are a large organization, I’d suggest you consider checking out some CRM platforms.</p> 
             <p>Regarding donations, you can always insert a PayPal donation widget into your website (you can do so with all the website makers listed above). Squarespace does have a donation tool, so definitely check them out as well. Their donation process is powered by Stripe (payment processing provider).</p> 
             <p>Jeremy</p> 
            </div> 
            <div class="reply"> 
             <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-305509" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-305509&quot;, &quot;305509&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
            </div> 
           </div> 
          </article> 
         </div> </li>
