            <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-305283" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
            <span class="edit"></span> 
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-305283"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Hi Doctrinam,</p> 
             <p>I think it really depends (sorry I can’t be more precise here). If you are just looking to build a simpler page structure (written content, pictures), then any one of the website makers will work. </p> 
             <p>But if you are looking to build a much more sophisticated system, such as PriceGrabber, then you’ll need a pretty customized platform to do so. The drag and drop website makers will not be effective in this case. You’ll most likely need to speak to a custom developer and the website will be quite expensive to develop.</p> 
             <p>Jeremy</p> 
            </div> 
            <div class="reply"> 
             <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-305283" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-305283&quot;, &quot;305283&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a>

        <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor even thread-even depth-1"> <a name="comment-305282"></a> 
         <div id="li-comment-305282" class="comment-container"> 
          <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
           <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-305282"> 
           <div class="avatar">
            <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-head"> 
            <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
            <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">October 14, 2015 at 11:20 AM</span> 
            <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-305282" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
            <span class="edit"></span> 
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-305282"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Hello Carmen,</p> 
             <p>You can certainly create pages of content using any of the website creators above (such as Wix as you mentioned). So you don’t necessarily have to use their blog features to insert your affiliate links or advertising banners. </p> 
             <p>However, if you don’t use the blog structure to create your content, you won’t be able to categorize your content, as only blog posts have the ability to assign categories or tags. </p> 
             <p>Regarding collection of emails, you can use newsletter service providers such as Aweber of Mailchimp. They’re quite popular and I believe you can integrate them into the website creators as a widget. I know that Aweber has a pop up feature where people can sign up through the pop up screen. </p> 
             <p>But also consider Wix or Jimdo, as they both have built in newsletter functions. Take a look at Footnote 15 above. </p> 
             <p>Good luck!</p> 
             <p>Jeremy</p> 
            </div> 
            <div class="reply"> 
             <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-305282" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-305282&quot;, &quot;305282&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
            </div>

              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-305783" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-305783"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hi Jim,</p> 
               <p>Take a look at <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/professional-images-for-your-website/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">this page here</a> to see some recommended sources for both free and paid, high quality images. You don’t necessarily need to rely on the website builders to source the images for you (even though they have libraries). You can definitely get them yourself and upload them into your website.</p> 
               <p>Weebly also has customizable templates, as they allow you to edit the codes to the template. So if you are a bit handy with codes, Weebly offers you a lot of flexibility. If not, I’d stick with Wix as they do give you tools to modify your design without having to touch any codes.</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div>

          <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor even depth-2"> <a name="comment-305287"></a> 
           <div id="li-comment-305287" class="comment-container"> 
            <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
             <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-305287"> 
             <div class="avatar">
              <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">October 14, 2015 at 11:38 AM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-305287" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-305287"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hey Que,</p> 
               <p>Both Wix and Squarespace will be able to do what you’re looking for.</p> 
               <p>Wix does have its own newsletter function called Wix Shoutout (take a look at our discussion under Footnote 15 above). With Squarespace, you should be able to integrate Mailchimp or Aweber, which are independent newsletter services provider.</p> 
               <p>To allow people to post answers, you will need to use blog posts in order to do so. Wix uses Facebook commenting system so that works fine (see Footnote 12 above)</p> 
               <p>Both Wix and Squarespace do provide social sharing features as well.</p> 
               <p>So it sounds like both website builders will be able to cater to your needs. So I’d suggest you sign up for free accounts with them and actually test out which builder you prefer to work with. That’s the only way you can be sure!</p> 
               <p>We also have a <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wix-vs-squarespace/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Wix versus Squarespace discussion</a> post here. You might find it helpful.</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div> 
              <div class="reply"> 
               <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-305287" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-305287&quot;, &quot;305287&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
              </div> 
             </div>

           <div id="li-comment-304981" class="comment-container"> 
            <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
             <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-304981"> 
             <div class="avatar">

             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">October 5, 2015 at 8:50 PM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-304981" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-304981"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Ellie,</p> 
               <p>I would suggest building out a full ecommerce store using an online store builder such as Shopify. While you can definitely sell your products on Facebook (<a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/how-to-set-up-a-facebook-store/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">using tools provided by Shopify</a>), it’s always preferable to have a selling platform outside of social networks.</p> 
               <p>As for pricing, I really can’t help you much on that. All I can say is to test your assumptions and see how your audience react accordingly!</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div>

         <div id="li-comment-304565" class="comment-container"> 
          <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
           <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-304565"> 
           <div class="avatar">
            <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-head"> 
            <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
            <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">September 22, 2015 at 11:17 AM</span> 
            <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-304565" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
            <span class="edit"></span> 
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-304565"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Hello Rashelle,</p> 
             <p>We haven’t tested Muse extensively as we haven’t used it for our own projects before. But based on what I know, it is a bit more advanced in terms of user interface, when compared to the website makers we’ve highlighted above. Muse shares a similar user interface as Photoshop (also created by Adobe), which a lot of users find a bit challenging to learn. I heard that other website makers such as Wix or Weebly are much more user-friendly.</p> 
             <p>But if you’re comfortable with Photoshop, then using Muse will feel a lot more “natural” for you.</p> 
             <p>Jeremy</p> 
            </div> 
            <div class="reply"> 
             <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-304565" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-304565&quot;, &quot;304565&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
            </div>

             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-304424"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hi Joanne,</p> 
               <p>I know what you mean, and I’m not an old dinosaur yet! When I first started, I was clueless and confused as to what these techie terms meant as well.</p> 
               <p>Take a look at <a href="http://www.webopedia.com/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Webopedia</a> or <a href="http://techterms.com/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">TechTerms</a>. Type in what you want defined in their search bars and you’ll get an overall explanation. Wikipedia may also be helpful as well. Once you get more into website building, it gets a bit easier!</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div>

             <p>Hi Jeremy, I own a day spa and have a website built with Simplesite.          <ul class="children"> 
          <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor even depth-2"> <a name="comment-304233"></a> 
           <div id="li-comment-304233" class="comment-container"> 
            <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
             <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-304233"> 
             <div class="avatar">
              <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">September 11, 2015 at 9:46 PM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-304233" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-304233"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hi Kay,</p> 
               <p>If you prefer a mobile responsive website, I’d suggest taking a look at Squarespace or Weebly. All the design templates that Squarespace provide are responsive, and the newer templates with Weebly are responsive.</p> 
               <p>Squarespace allow you to export your content into WordPress. Weebly allows you to export all your website codes, but you will have to know how to edit codes to make changes once you are outside of Weebly’s editing platform. Take a look at Footnote 10 above.</p> 
               <p>Hope this points you in the right direction!</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div> 
              <div class="reply"> 
               <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-304233" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-304233&quot;, &quot;304233&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
              </div> 
             </div> 
            </article> 
           </div> </li> 
         </ul> </li>

           </div> 
          </article> 
         </div> 
         <ul class="children"> 
          <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor even depth-2"> <a name="comment-304035"></a> 
           <div id="li-comment-304035" class="comment-container"> 
            <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
             <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-304035"> 
             <div class="avatar">
              <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">September 4, 2015 at 2:09 PM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-304035" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-304035"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hello Lauri,</p> 
               <p>Wix currently doesn’t allow you to add multiple editors to a single website. We’ve mentioned this under Footnote 18 above. But Weebly and Squarespace do allow you to do this.</p> 
               <p>As for your last question – I don’t think it’s necessarily true. If you build a very helpful and content rich website, and promote it properly, you can rank very well in Google search results. We’ve done that before ourselves in our past projects.</p> 
               <p>Some people believe that WordPress is much better, but there are also thousands and thousands of WordPress websites that do not rank well in Google search results. So it really depends on what you do with your website, and a lot less dependent on which website builder you use. That’s just my own view and experience!</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div> 
              <div class="reply"> 
               <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-304035" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-304035&quot;, &quot;304035&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
              </div>

        <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1"> <a name="comment-303814"></a> 
         <div id="li-comment-303814" class="comment-container"> 
          <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
           <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-303814"> 
           <div class="avatar">

           </div> 
           <div class="comment-head"> 
            <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Tyler</span> </span> 
            <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">August 29, 2015 at 5:40 AM</span> 
            <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-303814" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span>

           </div> 
           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-303814"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>I recently signed up with Web.com but they are charging me $114.95 per month for our website. I’m looking to switch and create a website for our small business that my wife and I run. We are starting from scratch with no customers and I think I’ve narrowed down my search to Wix, Squarespace and weebly. I like them all and I like the SEO friendliness of Squarespace and Wix, but Wix doesn’t have a responsive website design which I know google likes. Squarespace doesn’t offer phone support to where I can call in with questions with support. They all seem to be priced about the same so any recommendations to help get our business launched? Really looking to have the website bring in new business for the monthly service we provide. No ecommerce necessary.</p> 
            </div> 
            <div class="reply"> 
             <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-303814" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-303814&quot;, &quot;303814&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Tyler">Reply</a>

         <ul class="children"> 
          <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor even depth-2"> <a name="comment-303876"></a> 
           <div id="li-comment-303876" class="comment-container"> 
            <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
             <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-303876"> 
             <div class="avatar">
              <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">August 31, 2015 at 11:14 AM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-303876" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-303876"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hey Tyler,</p> 
               <p>Sorry to hear about Web. </p> 
               <p>Wix doesn’t have responsive designs, but they do offer you a mobile editor to edit the mobile version of your website. </p> 
               <p>The advantage of having a mobile editor for a separate mobile site is that you can have control over the design and layout of the mobile version of your website. You can control how a piece of content looks, where it is placed, and you can even remove it from being displayed on your mobile site (and have it still appear on the desktop version of your website). </p> 
               <p>So Wix’s mobile editor offers you more control, while with a responsive design you don’t have any control over the design / layout of your content (unless you know how to modify the codes to the template).</p> 
               <p>The drawback of using a mobile editor, is that you have to spend a bit more time editing the mobile site. But once you have to configured it’s just a bit of maintenance going forward. </p> 
               <p>So at the end of the day it’s a personal preference. I’m can’t say for certainty that Google prefer mobile responsive websites (such as Squarespace) over separate mobile sites (such as Wix). I think as long as there is some sort of mobile site, then you’ll be okay.</p> 
               <p>Have you also considered Weebly? They do offer you some mobile responsive templates, and do have phone support.</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div> 
              <div class="reply"> 
               <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-303876" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-303876&quot;, &quot;303876&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
              </div> 
             </div> 
            </article> 
           </div> </li> 
         </ul> </li> 
        <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1"> <a name="comment-303724"></a> 
         <div id="li-comment-303724" class="comment-container"> 
          <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
           <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-303724"> 
           <div class="avatar">
            <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-head"> 
            <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
            <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">August 26, 2015 at 5:10 PM</span> 
            <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-303724" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
            <span class="edit"></span> 
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-303724"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Hello Zi Yan,</p> 
             <p>When building websites, it’s best to size your images according to how big you want it to actually appear on your webpages. So if you can, try not to use the resizing function provided by the website creators. Use an image editor and actually shrink the images there, rather than using the drag and drop tools to resize your images. Also, if you want to compress the file sizes without losing too much quality (so you can have webpages that load faster), try using <a href="http://compressjpeg.com/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">this tool</a> here. We use it ourselves as well.</p> 
             <p>If you want to consider another website creator, I’d suggest <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/go/squarespacechart" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Squarespace</a>. Their designs are quite suitable for photographers and designers. They do offer a 14 day free trial period so you can give them a test drive to see how they work out for you.</p> 
             <p>Jeremy</p> 
            </div> 
            <div class="reply"> 
             <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-303724" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-303724&quot;, &quot;303724&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
            </div> 
           </div>

         <div id="li-comment-303559" class="comment-container"> 
          <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
           <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-303559"> 
           <div class="avatar">

           <div class="comment-head">

            <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">August 21, 2015 at 10:01 AM</span> 
            <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-303559" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
            <span class="edit"></span> 
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-303559"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Hi John,</p> 
             <p>Squarespace is the only website creator referenced above that has built in website tools for podcasts. With Squarespace, you can also create blog posts, and sell digital products. The only downside is that their ecommerce check out (for selling digital products) only integrates with one payment processor (Stripe). But Stripe is quite popular and easy to set up, so shouldn’t be a major hurdle.</p> 
             <p>You can also integrate with Google Analytics to get your traffic data, or use their built in Squarespace Metrics.</p> 
             <p>Hope this helps!</p> 
             <p>Jeremy</p> 
            </div>

             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-303401"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hello Bryttiny,</p> 
               <p>If the ecommerce set up is fairly basic (just information, images, add to cart button and a check out process), then Wix, Squarespace, Weebly or Jimdo will get the job done.</p> 
               <p>You can have a look at our <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/e-commerce-online-store-builders-comparison-chart/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">ecommerce comparison chart here</a>, which will give you a high level breakdown of each website builder. Shopify and Bigcommerce are a lot more advanced and so I think they’ll be beyond what you need (and they’re pricier as well).</p> 
               <p>Hope this points you in the right direction!</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div>

        <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1"> <a name="comment-303328"></a>

           </div> 
           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-302978"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Hi Jan,</p> 
             <p>Give Weebly a try, as they are probably one of the easiest, most user friendly website makers available in the market. They’re free to use, and their lowest plan is a few dollars per month. By upgrading to their lowest plan, you can remove their advertisement, and can use your own custom domain name which will give your site a much more professional look and feel.</p> 
             <p>Jeremy</p>

               <p>Hi John,</p> 
               <p>At the moment, Wix doesn’t have the feature where you can charge your members a fee to access restricted pages. Have a look at Sentry Login, which is an independent widget that apparently can help add that function to a Wix website.</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p>

         <ul class="children"> 
          <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor even depth-2"> <a name="comment-302605"></a> 
           <div id="li-comment-302605" class="comment-container"> 
            <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
             <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-302605"> 
             <div class="avatar">
              <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">July 27, 2015 at 11:13 AM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-302605" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-302605"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hi Niels,</p> 
               <p>Thanks for sharing your experiences and glad to hear that you were able to build a website with Weebly yourself.</p> 
               <p>To be honest, most of the website builders here will have the basic mechanics for you to configure your website SEO settings. The configurations won’t be as flexible as using other more powerful builders (such as WordPress), but in my view they’re good enough. Bear in mind the 80/20 rule, so you don’t spend all 80% of your time trying to perfect the other 20%. You might be better off spending your energy elsewhere to yield a higher return for your business.</p> 
               <p>But if your concern is that you want to customize your Weebly website beyond what is capable / could be handled by Weebly, then it’s really a case by case situation, as some other website builders will offer certain features that Weebly won’t. And if these features are really critical for your business, then a migration may be justified. But as you know, migrating a website is a big investment in time and energy. So make sure you know exactly what you are looking for before you migrate.</p> 
               <p>One way of exploring what features a website builder offer (that Weebly does not), is to sign up for a free / trial account and just play around with the platform. </p> 
               <p>Hope this helps somewhat!</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div> 
              <div class="reply"> 
               <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-302605" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-302605&quot;, &quot;302605&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
              </div> 
             </div> 
            </article> 
           </div> </li> 
         </ul> </li>

            <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

             <div class="avatar">

             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">July 27, 2015 at 10:59 AM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-302603" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-302603"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hi Rosa,</p> 
               <p>I think that Wix, Squarespace and Jimdo supports background videos. For Squarespace, I think it only works with their Cover Page layouts. With Wix and Jimdo, you can use video backgrounds even with their normal pages.</p> 
               <p>See the tutorials for <a href="https://www.wix.com/support/html5/new-wix-editor-june-2015/background/kb/adding-a-video-to-your-page-background" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Wix</a>, <a href="https://support.squarespace.com/hc/en-us/articles/206544107" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Squarespace</a> and <a href="http://support.jimdo.com/design/backgrounds/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Jimdo</a> here.</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div>

        <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1"> <a name="comment-302227"></a> 
         <div id="li-comment-302227" class="comment-container"> 
          <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
           <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-302227"> 
           <div class="avatar">
            <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-head"> 
            <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
            <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">July 17, 2015 at 11:53 AM</span> 
            <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-302227" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
            <span class="edit"></span> 
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-302227"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Hi Andy,</p> 
             <p>All the above website creators should be able to do what you want to do. They all have the ability to embed codes (so you can insert external widgets), but the question is how well will the widget work for each website creator, as the widget creator may not have created the widget to work specifically with a particular web builder.</p> 
             <p>So the best way forward is to sign up for a few website creators and see which one you like to work with. It is very subjective and I wished I could tell you which exact platform is best for you. Unfortunately, it’s really a trial and error type of exercise, to see which one you prefer. I’d suggest you test out Wix, Squarespace and Weebly as those are the top 3 web builders we suggest at the current moment!</p> 
             <p>Good luck!</p> 
             <p>Jeremy</p> 
            </div> 
            <div class="reply"> 
             <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-302227" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-302227&quot;, &quot;302227&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
            </div> 
           </div> 
          </article> 
         </div> </li>

        <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1"> <a name="comment-302080"></a> 
         <div id="li-comment-302080" class="comment-container"> 
          <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
           <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-302080"> 
           <div class="avatar">
            <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-head"> 
            <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
            <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">July 13, 2015 at 4:44 PM</span> 
            <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-302080" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
            <span class="edit"></span> 
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-302080"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Hi there,</p> 
             <p>You can use the platform for free, but like the drag &amp; drop website makers discussed here, you will have to upgrade in order to get access to more features, such as the ability to use your own domain name (instead of example.wordpress.com), remove WordPress advertisements, get direct support, and numerous other tools. I think they start at $99 per year, and the top plan is $299 per year.</p> 
             <p>Jeremy</p> 
            </div> 
            <div class="reply"> 
             <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-302080" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-302080&quot;, &quot;302080&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a>

             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-302051"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hi Bill,</p> 
               <p>I’m not aware of such a user interface with either Squarespace or Wix. But Wix does allow you to create a membership portal (using one of its App) where only members can log into see certain pages. You can <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/go/wixmembership" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">take a look at the App</a> here.</p> 
               <p>Alternatively, <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/go/weeblychart" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Weebly also has a membership login</a> tool that you can check out as well. </p> 
               <p>Good luck!</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p>

          <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor odd alt depth-2"> <a name="comment-301682"></a> 
           <div id="li-comment-301682" class="comment-container"> 
            <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
             <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-301682"> 
             <div class="avatar">
              <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">July 4, 2015 at 10:47 AM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-301682" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-301682"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hey Richard,</p> 
               <p>Have a <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/go/squarespacechart" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">look at Squarespace</a> as they do allow you to create either a custom checkout form or custom product form if you use their ecommerce tools. So you can ask your customers to leave their detailed information in multiple fields so you can collect those data for your needs.</p> 
               <p>Be aware that with Squarespace, they only use Stripe to power their shopping cart to manage payments. But Stripe is a good payment processor and Squarespace makes it pretty easy to set up. </p> 
               <p>You can also have a look at Shopify or Bigcommerce as their production functions are very customizable as well (see our <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/e-commerce-online-store-builders-comparison-chart/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">ecommerce builder comparison table</a> here).</p> 
               <p>Hope this helps!</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div> 
              <div class="reply"> 
               <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-301682" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-301682&quot;, &quot;301682&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
              </div> 
             </div> 
            </article> 
           </div> </li>

        <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1"> <a name="comment-301487"></a> 
         <div id="li-comment-301487" class="comment-container"> 
          <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
           <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-301487"> 
           <div class="avatar">
            <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-head"> 
            <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
            <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">June 30, 2015 at 6:28 AM</span> 
            <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-301487" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
            <span class="edit"></span> 
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-301487"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Hi Herb,</p> 
             <p>You can actually see our <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/e-commerce-online-store-builders-comparison-chart/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">ecommerce online store comparison chart</a> here. We do benchmark Shopify against other online store builders.</p> 
             <p>As for Wix, the main reason why you can’t transfer websites for Wix is that their proprietary drag &amp; drop system can’t be found with other platforms. For instance, if you want to move your content to Squarespace, or even WordPress, both of those website creators are not using the same building platform technology as Wix. As such, you can’t just move the codes over and have them work. </p> 
             <p>Hope this helps!</p> 
             <p>Jeremy</p> 
            </div> 
            <div class="reply"> 
             <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-301487" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-301487&quot;, &quot;301487&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
            </div> 
           </div> 
          </article> 
         </div> </li>

           <div class="comment-head"> 
            <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
            <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">June 25, 2015 at 9:39 PM</span> 
            <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-301326" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
            <span class="edit"></span> 
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-301326"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Hi Sarah,</p> 
             <p>WordPress is probably the best platform if you are focused on blogging as they have great blogging tools compared to the drag and drop website creators we’ve referenced above. However, one of the challenges of using WordPress is that if you want to use it proficiently, you’ll have to know a bit of codes (or working with someone who knows code). If you don’t, it makes it quite challenging to adjust designs and integrate (some) tools. We have a number of discussion posts that talks about how some of the <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/category/wordpress/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">website builders compare to using WordPress here</a>.</p> 
             <p>If you want to use a platform which requires no knowledge of code at all, and has decent tools for blogging while having an option to sell products on the side, I’d suggest you take a look at Squarespace or Wix (see our notes on blogging above). One thing about Squarespace is that their ecommerce shopping cart is only compatible with <a href="https://stripe.com/global" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Stripe</a> but it’s quite easy to integrate. With Wix, you have more shopping cart options.</p> 
             <p>You can also take a look at our <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/e-commerce-online-store-builders-comparison-chart/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">comparison chart for ecommerce builder</a> here. You can probably ignore Shopify and Bigcommerce as they are “pure” ecommerce builders, and are more suitable for dedicated online stores.</p> 
             <p>Jeremy</p> 
            </div> 
            <div class="reply"> 
             <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-301326" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-301326&quot;, &quot;301326&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
            </div> 
           </div> 
          </article> 
         </div> </li>

             <p>Hi Jeremy! Thank you for an excellent service you’re providing!</p> 
             <p>I have a website which I build using Weebly through Bluehost. I think it would be a good idea to switch to a website builder, e.g. Weebly.com and start using it directly due to more functionality, ability to use updates immediately, etc. So, now I’d like to make a choice of a website builder (because it doesn’t necessarily be Weebly). In my view, Weebly is simple, but offers considerable limitations in the variability of design options. I guess, however, that it applies to all WYSIWYG builders, and I am not prepared to devote considerate time to master WordPress.</p> 
             <p>My website is about the best places to visit in cities. It’s http:\\theplacestovisit.com I need to have the following:<br> – Many pages, easily 300+ in a year, a good page tree (several layers)<br> – Mostly text pages with a few pictures + functional maps<br> – Good comment section, like the one on this your page<br> – Not very high requirements to the design<br> – Social buttons as Facebook, Twitter, etc.<br> – Ability to sell digital products (e-books).</p>

           <div id="li-comment-300012" class="comment-container"> 
            <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
             <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-300012"> 
             <div class="avatar">
              <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">May 29, 2015 at 10:02 PM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-300012" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-300012"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hi Dmitry,</p> 
               <p>Thanks for your comment. What you have in mind is indeed a pretty large website (300 pages)! If you want a good page tree structure, using Weebly.com is a good option as they are pretty flexible there. </p> 
               <p>But at the end of the day, if you are going to building that many pages, WordPress might be an option for you to consider as their content management system is good which enables you to make site wide updates a lot quicker than drag and drop builders. WordPress’ commenting system is also top notch. </p> 
               <p>The only drawback is that WordPress does have a higher learning curve, but once you invest the time to learn it, it’s not too bad at all (assuming you are just building a more basic website, as if you want to build in all sorts of features or have a lot of design flexibility, it can get tricky as you may have to deal with codes).</p> 
               <p>As for <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/how-to-build-a-multi-language-website/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">building a bilingual website, we have a discussion post here</a>.</p> 
               <p>Hope this helps!</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div>

             <ul class="children"> 
              <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor odd alt depth-4"> <a name="comment-301167"></a> 
               <div id="li-comment-301167" class="comment-container"> 
                <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
                 <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-301167"> 
                 <div class="avatar">
                  <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
                 </div> 
                 <div class="comment-head"> 
                  <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
                  <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">June 21, 2015 at 9:37 PM</span> 
                  <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-301167" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
                  <span class="edit"></span> 
                 </div> 
                 <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-301167"> 
                  <div itemprop="text">
                   <p>Hi Dmitry,</p> 
                   <p>I suspect for what you are trying to build, you can use either platform. WordPress is a bit more complex but has more advanced tools to help you better manage all your content (300 pages is a lot!), and Weebly is much easier to use, but their management tools are not as good when managing a huge website.</p> 
                   <p>For instance, if you need to re-use an image multiple times, with Weebly, you’ll have to re-upload the same image over and over again as they don’t have a database for you to grab the same image to insert into a specific page. With WordPress, once you upload an image once, you can grab the same image easily without having to upload it again.</p> 
                   <p>Also, if you want to highlight / spotlight certain pages, WordPress allows you to link those pages and showcase them in an automated way. With Weebly, you will have to manually build the showcase section.</p> 
                   <p>But the challenge with doing that with WordPress is that you will have to look for the right theme to use, and it is likely that you will have to make (code) modifications to your site to get it to work exactly how you want to. </p> 
                   <p>So there are definitely pros and cons to each, but if you are committed to learning WordPress and codes, I think for your unique needs, it will be a much easier platform for you to manage down the road.</p> 
                   <p>Here is a <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/weebly-vs-wordpress-whats-the-difference/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">short post where we compared Weebly and WordPress</a> that you might find interesting as well.</p> 
                   <p>Good luck!</p> 
                   <p>Jeremy</p> 
                  </div> 
                  <div class="reply"> 
                   <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-301167" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-301167&quot;, &quot;301167&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
                  </div> 
                 </div> 
                </article> 
               </div> </li> 
             </ul> </li> 
           </ul> </li> 
         </ul> </li> 
        <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1"> <a name="comment-299925"></a> 
         <div id="li-comment-299925" class="comment-container"> 
          <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
           <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-299925"> 
           <div class="avatar">
            <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/Logo-Avatar.png" width="40" height="40" alt="" class="avatar avatar-40wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo avatar-default">
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-head"> 
            <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Robert S</span> </span> 
            <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">May 28, 2015 at 9:51 AM</span> 
            <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-299925" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
            <span class="edit"></span> 
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-299925"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Jeremy:</p> 
             <p>Your website comparison reports are terrific and have been very helpful. Our needs are somewhat different than a traditional ecommerce business.</p> 
             <p>We are launching a new business offering a technology-enabled service. Customers will receive reminder messages at several user-specified times every day. Each message can have 1-30 reminder items which can vary from message-to-message. Thus, a customer account (order) is a 3-dimensional matrix of:</p> 
             <p>. Day (Monday-Sunday)<br> . 1-6 specific reminder times during each day (HH:MM)<br> . 1-30 specific items for each reminder time during each day with an item having several variable fields (e.g., description, amount, note, other). </p> 
             <p>We want customers to be able to setup &amp; maintain their account (enter &amp; maintain a standing order for the service) through our website.</p> 
             <p>Is there one or more website builder offering you suggest we focus on in our selection process? </p> 
             <p>If there isn’t an “out-of-the-box” solution, which offering(s) would get us closest to our requirements and need the least customization?</p> 
             <p>Thanks again for your time, effort and help.</p> 
             <p>Rob</p> 
            </div>

              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hi Cheryl,</p> 
               <p>I’d suggest checking out Wix or Weebly, as both of them are probably the easiest website builders to use in my view. They’re free to sign up and test, so it would be a good idea to give them both a test drive before deciding which one is better suited for your needs.</p> 
               <p>We also have an <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wix-vs-weebly-which-website-builder-is-better/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">article here to compares both of these website builders</a>, if you need a bit more details in regards to the differences between them.</p>

         <ul class="children"> 
          <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor even depth-2"> <a name="comment-299237"></a> 
           <div id="li-comment-299237" class="comment-container"> 
            <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
             <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-299237"> 
             <div class="avatar">
              <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">May 14, 2015 at 12:31 AM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-299237" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-299237"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hi Paul,</p> 
               <p>Both Wix and Squarespace have the ability for you to allow your visitors to make appointments. However, you will need to use external widgets / apps and integrate those into either your Wix or Squarespace website.</p> 
               <p>For Wix, their <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wix-app-market-review/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">App Market</a> has a few calendar / scheduling apps for you to integrate. For Squarespace, if you look in their <a href="http://help.squarespace.com/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">help center</a> (type “calendar”) you’ll see a few articles relating to integrating scheduling apps.</p> 
               <p>But I don’t think either of the allow the scheduling tools to be integrated with their ecommerce shopping cart.</p> 
               <p>What you can do is insert a product so people can purchase reservations. Once they’ve purchased the reservation slot, you can send them to the page where they can make a reservation. You can do this by inserting the instructions on which page to visit in the “thank you” email that gets sent to them once they’ve made a purchase (deposit for the reservation). You can create the scheduling page and just hide it, so only those who made the purchase will know whereto go.</p> 
               <p>It’s not a perfect solution, and is a long workaround, but just might work.</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div> 
              <div class="reply"> 
               <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-299237" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-299237&quot;, &quot;299237&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
              </div> 
             </div> 
            </article> 
           </div>

        <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor odd alt thread-even depth-1"> <a name="comment-298403"></a> 
         <div id="li-comment-298403" class="comment-container"> 
          <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
           <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-298403"> 
           <div class="avatar">
            <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-head"> 
            <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
            <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">April 25, 2015 at 7:26 PM</span> 
            <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-298403" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
            <span class="edit"></span> 
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-298403"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Purnima,</p> 
             <p>There really isn’t a very effective way of stopping people from copying your creative work. it’s just one of the downsides of the internet in that everyone can pretty much copy anything if he/she really wanted to. The same goes for the physical world as well but obviously with physical goods it takes a bit more effort, but still very much achievable. But hopefully that won’t discourage you from sharing your creative work with the rest of the world!</p> 
             <p>As for domain names, some of the website makers will give you a free domain name if you sign up to their annual plans (see chart details above). But you can also get your domain name from domain name registrars <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/go/godaddy" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">such as GoDaddy</a>, and connect it to your website.</p> 
             <p>As for which builder to use, the best way to go about choosing is to find the website maker that you enjoy using, as all of them are different from one another in terms of user interface and tools (to a certain extent). But I’d suggest taking a look at Squarespace and Wix to get started as they have some pretty good looking and creative templates.</p> 
             <p>Jeremy</p> 
            </div> 
            <div class="reply"> 
             <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-298403" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-298403&quot;, &quot;298403&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
            </div>

        <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1"> <a name="comment-298255"></a> 
         <div id="li-comment-298255" class="comment-container"> 
          <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
           <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-298255"> 
           <div class="avatar">
            <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/Logo-Avatar.png" width="40" height="40" alt="" class="avatar avatar-40wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo avatar-default">
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-head"> 
            <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Luc</span> </span> 
            <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">April 22, 2015 at 8:18 PM</span> 
            <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-298255" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
            <span class="edit"></span> 
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-298255"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Hi, great comparison first of all, very informative and helpful! </p> 
             <p>I have a few questions though. When conducting transactions online through these web hosts, are there any costs involved that goes to third parties?<br> Say i choose squarespace for my website and a customer decided to buy something off it, would some of the money in the ecommerce transaction be used for anything or anyone else besides me and the customer? Or are there no fees involved when setting up this eCommerce aspect of your site? </p> 
             <p>Thanks in advance!</p> 
            </div> 
            <div class="reply"> 
             <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-298255" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-298255&quot;, &quot;298255&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Luc">Reply</a> 
            </div> 
           </div> 
          </article> 
         </div> 
         <ul class="children"> 
          <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor even depth-2"> <a name="comment-298290"></a> 
           <div id="li-comment-298290" class="comment-container"> 
            <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
             <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-298290"> 
             <div class="avatar">
              <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">April 23, 2015 at 1:31 PM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-298290" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-298290"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Hi Luc,</p> 
               <p>There will be payment transaction fees. For instance, when you go shopping at a local store and you use your credit card, the merchant that sold you the product will have to pay Visa / Mastercard / Amex etc fees, which is a couple of percent of the total value of the transaction.</p> 
               <p>So it works the same way with online stores. If you use PayPal (or any other payment processors) to collect money from your customers, they will need to be paid for providing that service. You can find more information about such fees directly on the ecommerce web builder that you use, or on the payment processors’ websites but it’s usually something around 2% – 3%.</p> 
               <p>Some ecommerce builders also take a small percentage of your transaction value. But they will waive that fee if you upgrade to a higher plan (varies from builder to builder).</p> 
               <p>Hope this explains things a bit.</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div> 
              <div class="reply"> 
               <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-298290" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-298290&quot;, &quot;298290&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
              </div> 
             </div> 
            </article> 
           </div>

          <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor odd alt depth-2"> <a name="comment-298194"></a> 
           <div id="li-comment-298194" class="comment-container"> 
            <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
             <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-298194"> 
             <div class="avatar">
              <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">April 21, 2015 at 5:10 PM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-298194" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-298194"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>Stef,</p> 
               <p>Have a look at Weebly. They allow you full access to the HTML / CSS codes so you can make edits / customizations there if you want to. </p> 
               <p>They also provide hosting services (part of the package) and so you won’t have to use your own hosting services. In other words, if you want to use Weebly, you won’t be able to use them with your own hosting services.</p> 
               <p>If you have your own domain name, you can connect that to a Weebly site and they have tutorials on how to do that in their Help Center.</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div> 
              <div class="reply"> 
               <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-298194" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-298194&quot;, &quot;298194&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a>

         <div id="li-comment-296521" class="comment-container"> 
          <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
           <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-296521"> 
           <div class="avatar">
            <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-head"> 
            <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
            <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">April 12, 2015 at 5:57 PM</span> 
            <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-296521" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
            <span class="edit"></span> 
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-296521"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Hi Kate,</p> 
             <p>I don’t think any of the website creators discussed here will give you the capability to create a crowd source / visitor contribution type of website. Those sort of websites are much more complex and I suspect you will need to hire a very capable developer to help you custom build what you have in mind.</p> 
             <p>The website creators we’ve discussed here are great for building more “typical” sort of sites, such as business, ecommerce, photography / portfolio, blogs, hobbies, general content, where the site owner will create all the content.</p> 
             <p>Hope this guides you in the right direction!</p> 
             <p>Jeremy</p> 
            </div> 
            <div class="reply"> 
             <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-296521" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-296521&quot;, &quot;296521&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a>

          <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor odd alt depth-2"> <a name="comment-295147"></a>

        <li class="comment byuser comment-author-websitebuilderexpert bypostauthor even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1"> <a name="comment-294396"></a> 
         <div id="li-comment-294396" class="comment-container"> 
          <article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment"> 
           <meta itemprop="url" content="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#li-comment-294396"> 
           <div class="avatar">
            <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-head"> 
            <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
            <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">April 6, 2015 at 3:46 PM</span> 
            <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-294396" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
            <span class="edit"></span> 
           </div> 
           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-294396"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>Hey Alvin,</p> 
             <p>Thanks for your input. Weebly allows you to export a Weebly website to import it into another hosting service, but they don’t have a function for you to import it back into Weebly again. The same thing applies across other website makers discussed here as well. </p> 
             <p>I think the main reason is that each website maker’s platform has its unique code base (that enables you to drag and drop content to build out your website). So if you start tinkering with the codes after you export the site, if you are allowed to import the site back into the website maker (after you’ve modified the codes a bit), then the codes may not work properly and /or conflict with that website maker. </p> 
             <p>But if you want to move a website across to another account, give their support team a shout and they are likely able to do that. Granted, I haven’t tried that myself, but I don’t see a reason why that shouldn’t be a possible.</p> 
             <p>Good point though so thanks for bringing it up!</p> 
             <p>Jeremy</p> 
            </div> 
            <div class="reply"> 
             <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-294396" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-294396&quot;, &quot;294396&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a> 
            </div> 
           </div> 
          </article> 
         </div> </li>

           <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-294206"> 
            <div itemprop="text">
             <p>For export website, weebly should be “no.” One can export it to html, but you cannot export it to another weebly site nor use it with weebly again. In short, you can export it, but cannot import it back to weebly. That’s like saying you can do a backup, but cannot restore your backup. Absurd right?</p> 
            </div>

             <div class="avatar">
              <img src="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/jeremy_dec_2015.png" width="40" height="40" alt="Jeremy Wong" class="avatar avatar-40 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-40 alignnone photo">

             <div class="comment-head"> 
              <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"> <span class="name" itemprop="name">Jeremy Wong</span> </span> 
              <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished">March 25, 2015 at 2:31 PM</span> 
              <span class="perma"><a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/website-builders-comparison-chart/#comment-289677" title="Direct link to this comment">#</a></span> 
              <span class="edit"></span> 
             </div> 
             <div class="comment-entry" id="comment-289677"> 
              <div itemprop="text">
               <p>iPage is more of a hosting service, so not quite comparable to the website builders we’ve discussed in our table above. </p> 
               <p>They do offer you the ability to get a WordPress site hosted, and they also offer you the ability to use Weebly. So if you are thinking about using Weebly through iPage, you should take a look at our <a href="https://www.websitebuilderexpert.com/weebly-vs-weebly-with-bluehost/" title="Weebly vs Weebly with Bluehost" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">discussion about using Weebly.com directly and using Weebly with another hosting service</a>). There are definitely pros and cons to consider.</p> 
               <p>Jeremy</p> 
              </div> 
              <div class="reply"> 
               <a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="#comment-289677" onclick="return addComment.moveForm( &quot;comment-289677&quot;, &quot;289677&quot;, &quot;respond&quot;, &quot;1171&quot; )" aria-label="Reply to Jeremy Wong">Reply</a>
